.\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MACS0744-system3\u00a0</td><td>61\u00a0</td><td>266\u00a0</td><td>80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>230\u00a0\u00b1\u00a030\u00a0</td><td>1.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.8\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS1149-arcA1.1\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td><td>86\u00a0</td><td>59\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>88\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS0451-system7\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0</td><td>100\u00a0</td><td>100\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>77\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>220\u00a0\u00b1\u00a030\u00a0</td><td>1.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1413-arc2.1a\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td><td>172\u00a0</td><td>17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1413-arc2.1b\u00a0</td><td>66\u00a0</td><td>249\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1835-arc7.1\u00a0</td><td>89\u00a0</td><td>236\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>Undetermined\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MS1621-system1\u00a0</td><td>84\u00a0</td><td>247\u00a0</td><td>126\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1720-arc1.1+1.2\u00a0</td><td>70\u00a0</td><td>144\u00a0</td><td>63.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>27.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1689-arc2.1\u00a0</td><td>81\u00a0</td><td>38\u00a0</td><td>64\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1689-arc1.2\u00a0</td><td>80\u00a0</td><td>234\u00a0</td><td>78\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>53\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>1.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2895-arc1.1+1.2\u00a0</td><td>85\u00a0</td><td>260\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>62\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>Undetermined\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2895-arc2.2\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>276\u00a0</td><td>200\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>530\u00a0\u00b1\u00a030\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cl0024-arc1.1\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td><td>122\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08\u00a0</td><td>63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06\u00a0</td><td>15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>2.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cl0949-arc1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>68\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>16\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS0712-system1\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td><td>351\u00a0</td><td>33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>75\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>0.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACSJ0744-arc1\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td><td>124\u00a0</td><td>118\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>110\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>210\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>2.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cosmic Eye\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0</td><td>113\u00a0</td><td>51\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> Inclination and PA are derived from the best-fitting disc models. <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> is the velocity at 2.2<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, where <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> is the half-light radius. Velocity dispersion, \u03c3, is the luminosity-weighted mean local value, after deconvolving for local velocity gradient. The velocity gradient <em>v</em>/<em>r</em> is measured at <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>. Targets below the line are from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) with values reported in their table 2, except for <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub>, <em>v</em>/<em>r</em> and <em>v</em>/\u03c3, which we measure for consistency with the new data. No values for \u03b8, PA or <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> are given for Cl0949-arc1 as this galaxy cannot be fit by a disc model.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/17053636\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">While it is always possible to fit a rotating disc model to the data, this is insufficient to determine that the galaxy is a rotating disc. A rotating disc should have symmetric velocity and velocity dispersion fields, the latter peaking in the centre of the galaxy. The traditional requirement that the velocity field form a \u2018spider\u2019 pattern is rarely found in lensed galaxies due to the asymmetric magnification (the contours overlaid in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> demonstrate how much smoothing by the elliptical source-plane PSFs distorts even an idealized rotation field).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) illustrate the symmetry of the kinematics in their sample by extracting one-dimensional profiles along the kinematic axis, concluding that five of the six galaxies have velocity profiles indicative of rotation, with one likely merger (Cl0949-arc1). In order to examine the symmetry in our new data, we extract a one-dimensional profile of the velocity and velocity dispersion from each galaxy. We do this by using the best-fitting disc model to identify the dynamical centre and major kinematic axis of the galaxy. The velocity and velocity dispersion are extracted along a slit 5 pixels wide, and binned into independent resolution elements along the long axis according to the galaxies\u2019 effective source-plane PSF. The resulting dynamical profiles for the 12 galaxies in our sample are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The best-fitting one-dimensional rotation curves and exponential velocity dispersion profiles (where applicable) are overlaid in red.</p>                        <a id=\"17053639\" scrollto-destination=\"17053639\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=I7uSqErGktQsDArUUogBvEjhiInvnT6HZ3LnvnZaQVl9haXyPh7nmOH2oNuX5QxZ8M~BYh-LMtE8eQhuwaVWk1nztyPRXQf1yx3aqNCW6K87zpQiZyo70EbSbXcD68qr0X~yUNqvve1VOAQtyec79MS4NuvtyNs7gd977QRwP-NA8WQ1IuOfCUhYsMG~0eV7AVS8EH6LaqOYKn9jYQGUNv8AVWFz05i2p0zeleM9yCtgbcpTwa09qk-Ty6-OmCpwAb4en-FUiZEw0k8nUL1FsdOf2RTP2gfqLsqyXjC5wAt1GMEGWtXZz1r4yxfmBzqQjsNYLeTWzIqlxUCXt3oRaQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"One-dimensional rotation curves (left) and velocity dispersion profiles (right), extracted from a slit aligned along the axis of the best-fitting disc model. For the galaxies whose dynamics are well fit by a rotating disc model, we overlay the best-fitting rotation curve and velocity dispersion profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig2.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053639/stv686fig2.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig2.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053639\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=z6~up8YqAcUxxPtaqhjSDV9iqIrmf9YztNrKHzkKxGLBdoXxXbTlH1bocOJbMB7WU7Y7wVioMNy3R5GuPlqTIEYs6orO57OaBw2k~E854Nwp63D-651LcrwKROStEHoBqhMhMpB58ABt1KWhUeqi2VEnY-9oFbOIGM7GMhenrb81r~slsdk8zNqUlOcPK-w-QxI6Y6W-tL-Ra1Z-s-DZRvmoZTwTYhASIcG2zRUw5~oNNT0o0mqkcET0SB49WrrzVrstobgm3GZtt8~bWrWZQelHUNnaJmMVVWWNTxF2bt4CW3WgHAPQrygXRJtCbz7N6AICwoTEmq5zpT9sKkCvjA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053639&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig2.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">One-dimensional rotation curves (left) and velocity dispersion profiles (right), extracted from a slit aligned along the axis of the best-fitting disc model. For the galaxies whose dynamics are well fit by a rotating disc model, we overlay the best-fitting rotation curve and velocity dispersion profile.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=I7uSqErGktQsDArUUogBvEjhiInvnT6HZ3LnvnZaQVl9haXyPh7nmOH2oNuX5QxZ8M~BYh-LMtE8eQhuwaVWk1nztyPRXQf1yx3aqNCW6K87zpQiZyo70EbSbXcD68qr0X~yUNqvve1VOAQtyec79MS4NuvtyNs7gd977QRwP-NA8WQ1IuOfCUhYsMG~0eV7AVS8EH6LaqOYKn9jYQGUNv8AVWFz05i2p0zeleM9yCtgbcpTwa09qk-Ty6-OmCpwAb4en-FUiZEw0k8nUL1FsdOf2RTP2gfqLsqyXjC5wAt1GMEGWtXZz1r4yxfmBzqQjsNYLeTWzIqlxUCXt3oRaQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"One-dimensional rotation curves (left) and velocity dispersion profiles (right), extracted from a slit aligned along the axis of the best-fitting disc model. For the galaxies whose dynamics are well fit by a rotating disc model, we overlay the best-fitting rotation curve and velocity dispersion profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig2.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053639/stv686fig2.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig2.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053639\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=z6~up8YqAcUxxPtaqhjSDV9iqIrmf9YztNrKHzkKxGLBdoXxXbTlH1bocOJbMB7WU7Y7wVioMNy3R5GuPlqTIEYs6orO57OaBw2k~E854Nwp63D-651LcrwKROStEHoBqhMhMpB58ABt1KWhUeqi2VEnY-9oFbOIGM7GMhenrb81r~slsdk8zNqUlOcPK-w-QxI6Y6W-tL-Ra1Z-s-DZRvmoZTwTYhASIcG2zRUw5~oNNT0o0mqkcET0SB49WrrzVrstobgm3GZtt8~bWrWZQelHUNnaJmMVVWWNTxF2bt4CW3WgHAPQrygXRJtCbz7N6AICwoTEmq5zpT9sKkCvjA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053639&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig2.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">One-dimensional rotation curves (left) and velocity dispersion profiles (right), extracted from a slit aligned along the axis of the best-fitting disc model. For the galaxies whose dynamics are well fit by a rotating disc model, we overlay the best-fitting rotation curve and velocity dispersion profile.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the galaxies in the sample exhibit velocity gradients, and all can be fit by an arctan function. However, we only see indications of a turnover in the rotation curve in 9/12 of the sample. Furthermore, the velocity dispersion profiles are less ordered. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we attempt to fit an exponential profile to the velocity dispersions. In 50\u2009per\u2009cent of cases, the exponential function is a good fit to the data. In two cases, A1413-arc2.1b and RXJ1720-arc1.1+1.2, there is no central peak. A1413-arc2.1b is probably interacting with the larger A1413-arc2.1a, from which it is offset by only \u223c1000\u2009km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and the morphology of RXJ1720-arc1.1+1.2 with its extended tail suggests that it also may be an interacting system. In the remaining four galaxies \u2013 MACS0744-system3, A1413-arc2.1a, MS1621-system1 and A1689-arc1.2 \u2013 there are suggestions of a double peak in the velocity dispersion profile, which may also be indicative of a late-stage merger. Alternatively, the irregular and asymmetric profiles could be due to turbulence within the discs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The kinematic properties of the galaxies are similar to those in the Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample, which also exhibited rotation-like velocity fields with irregular velocity dispersion profiles. The galaxies in the new sample tend to be smaller than those from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), with median <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5\u2009 and 1.2\u00a0kpc, respectively, but both lensed samples probe systematically smaller galaxies than unlensed studies such as SINS+AO, SHiZELS and WiggleZ, which have median <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a04.3, 2.3 and 2.5\u00a0kpc, respectively (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>; Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The two lensed samples are closely matched in rotational velocity with median rotational velocity measured at 2.2\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> of <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a064 and 51\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> for the new data and Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample, respectively. The median rotational velocity in the WiggleZ survey is marginally higher at 74\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, with \u223c110\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in SHiZELS and \u223c150\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the SINS AO sample. There are two factors that bias lensing surveys towards more slowly rotating systems: first, that they are sensitive to smaller galaxies, which tend to be slower rotators (e.g. Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, see also Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1.1</a>), and secondly, the high spatial resolution enables us to measure small velocity gradients that would be flattened by beam smearing in unlensed data and thus categorized as non-rotating.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As the properties of the two lensed samples are similar, and differ systematically from the unlensed data, we discuss them in the remainder of this paper as a combined sample. In the interest of providing a comparison to other studies, we give our best estimate of the nature of the galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, but caution that these are by no means certain.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053643 id=\"17053643\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5>2.5 SED fitting and stellar mass estimates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to estimate the extinction due to dust and the stellar masses of our sample, we model their spectral energy distributions (SEDs) from available archival <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC imaging. We first subtract any foreground cluster members lying close to the line of sight to the target galaxy, using the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> tasks <span class=\"monospace\">ellipse</span> and <span class=\"monospace\">bmodel</span>. We then degrade all of the imaging for each galaxy to the poorest resolution, that of the longest wavelength IRAC band. We then extract the photometry using an elliptical aperture large enough to encompass the galaxy, with a 2\u00a0arcsec annulus for sky subtraction. We apply aperture corrections to the IRAC fluxes based on the area of the aperture used.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As the continuum light does not necessarily follow the same distribution as the nebular emission, we do not assume the same magnification factor from gravitational lensing; instead, the measured fluxes are corrected for lensing using the flux-weighted mean magnification within the aperture, from magnification maps created with <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>. The resulting magnification factors are within 1\u03c3 of the values given for the nebular emission in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The complete photometry, corrected for lensing, is given in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> in the appendix. When calculating stellar masses, we omit the arcs in three clusters that do not have imaging in at least two bands either side of the 4000\u2009\u00c5 break (MS1621, RXJ1720 and Abell 2895), as well as the galaxy A1413-arc2.1b which is undetected in the <em>HST</em> imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform the SED fitting using the <span class=\"small-caps\">cigale</span> code (Noll et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). We use the stellar population models of Maraston (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), allow either exponentially decreasing or continuous star formation histories and constrain the oldest stellar populations to be younger than the age of the Universe at the target redshift. The <span class=\"small-caps\">cigale</span> code creates SEDs from the far-ultraviolet to the infrared based on a dust-attenuated stellar population, infrared dust emission and spectral line templates. The best-fitting galaxy parameters are derived with a Bayesian-like analysis from the distribution of probability-weighted best-fitting models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stellar masses and dust extinction, <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>, obtained for each galaxy from the SED fit is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. We find stellar masses of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u20132\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>; thus, lensing allows us to probe systematically smaller galaxies than unlensed samples such as SINS (median <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>; F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) or SHiZELS (median <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). The dust extinctions we derive are in the range <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.4\u20131.1 with a median <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.9, similar to those of SINS (<em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.8; F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and SHiZELS (<em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.9; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"17053648\" class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> All quantities are corrected for lensing magnification. SFR is calculated from the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 luminosity corrected for dust extinction based on <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>. The half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1</sub>/2 is based on the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 morphology as described in the text. <em>A</em><sub><em>v</em></sub> and <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> are estimated from SED fitting of broad-band photometry as described in the text, except for those marked (<em>a</em>), which are from Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Targets below the line are from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), with SFRs given in their table 2 and half-light radii reported by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MACS0744-system3\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>1.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1\u00a0</td><td>9.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS1149-arcA1.1\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>9.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS0451-system7\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>0.18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>8.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1413-arc2.1a\u00a0</td><td>34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>6.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>0.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>8.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>0.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1413-arc2.1b\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1835-arc7.1\u00a0</td><td>2.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>8.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>1.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MS1621-system1\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1720-arc1.1+1.2\u00a0</td><td>3.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>1.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1689-arc2.1\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5\u00a0</td><td> Eye\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>10.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> All quantities are corrected for lensing magnification. SFR is calculated from the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 luminosity corrected for dust extinction based on <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>. The half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1</sub>/2 is based on the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 morphology as described in the text. <em>A</em><sub><em>v</em></sub> and <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> are estimated from SED fitting of broad-band photometry as described in the text, except for those marked (<em>a</em>), which are from Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Targets below the line are from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), with SFRs given in their table 2 and half-light radii reported by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/17053648\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stellar masses and dust extinctions of the Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample and A1835-arc7.1 of the new observations are derived by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and given in their table 4. We note that the method used is similar to the one we employ, so the results can be directly compared.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053650 id=\"17053650\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-6>2.6 Integrated galaxy properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now derive some integrated properties of the sample, so that we can relate the lensed galaxies to the population as a whole and explore how their internal structures evolve as a function of their global properties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A summary of the integrated properties of the sample is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. Total fluxes of the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission lines are calculated by summing every pixel in the source-plane cubes with S/N &gt;5. We measure the total flux by fitting a Gaussian profile to the emission lines, and the ratio of the total flux in the image plane to that in the source plane gives the total magnification given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Intrinsic SFRs in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> are calculated from the H\u03b1 (or H\u03b2, assuming case B recombination) flux, corrected for dust according to the extinction <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub> derived from SED fitting, by applying the Kennicutt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998a</a>) prescription. We correct this conversion to a Chabrier initial mass function (IMF), which includes a turnover at the low-mass end and produces more realistic mass-to-light ratios. This correction has the effect of reducing the SFR by a factor 1.7.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To find the half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, we first construct an array in which each pixel value is the distance from the dynamical centre, [<em>i</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>, <em>j</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>], based on an estimated position angle, \u03d5, and inclination (\u03b8; the derivation of the dynamical centre, position angle and inclination is discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1</a>). The result is a series of concentric ellipses with the galactocentric radius in pixel <em>i</em>, <em>j</em> given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nr_{i,j} = \\sqrt{ \\left( x\\cos \\phi + y\\sin \\phi \\right)^2 + \\left( \\frac{x\\sin \\phi - y\\cos \\phi }{\\cos \\theta }\\right)^2},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where <em>x</em>\u00a0=\u00a0|<em>i</em> \u2212 <em>i</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>| and <em>y</em>\u00a0=\u00a0|<em>j</em> \u2212 <em>j</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>|. We then convolve this array with the flux-weighted source-plane PSF, to account for the fact that the preferential direction of magnification causes the source-plane images to appear smeared in one direction.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Starting from the dynamical centre, we then sum the flux within contours of constant <em>r</em>, incrementing <em>r</em> until half the total flux is enclosed. This then gives the half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. The half-light sizes we find are in the range <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2\u20132.1\u00a0kpc. Where we have rest-frame optical imaging of a galaxy we carry out the same procedure and find that the results are consistent within the quoted errors. The half-light radii of the Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample are <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.5\u20133.5\u00a0kpc. As noted in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a>, we find galaxies that are systematically smaller than those observed in unlensed samples due to the lensing magnification. We illustrate the selection of the lensed galaxies in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> by comparing the SFRs and stellar masses of the lensed arcs to similar unlensed samples.</p>                        <a id=\"17053656\" scrollto-destination=\"17053656\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=3X5ZkpHJ4XSd-44jcOk4SEhW0By70j1n~YvVEXyPEZF0-dXdUzSD~MNgnUnEDM1u4eYDdY0RZRsenBj6asd-Pe5naRGsb~XyETmFME-kgGVEy3pTEk8HYGXjUTeYY6O8a5CUfZdSVeJVFM8ZglUfcywQC6oYrlswP-mmFo3o2wVgEsmVyoSYDZcPdHQhaV96l~HIy7dYDc1YzpKNK5KJvYVMG0lNrzB~VqbixPSnmN90h7O9tr1-YTjVVQQqm-HEQpM8bahnpJmad8kslJqzdPDQ96RgkZCCSqbIthUbmEF3bwDSfQSzDjoyxjWjimOuZUfjtf9soqj1HzLvpHVtOQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Total galaxy SFR against stellar mass for the lensed arcs for which we are able to derive stellar masses, in comparison with other high-redshift kinematic studies. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines indicate the star-forming galaxy \u2018main sequence\u2019 at z\u00a0=\u00a00, 1 and 2.5 (Whitaker et\u00a0al. 2012). Comparison data are from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012a), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. 2013), and the grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS points. The lensed arcs, as well as the WiggleZ and SHiZELS samples, are similar to z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01 main-sequence star-forming galaxies, though the lensed arcs probe the lower mass end of the relation. The SINS AO sample covers higher specific SFRs, similar to the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.5 star-forming main sequence.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig3.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053656/stv686fig3.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig3.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053656\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=1c6wQTsjVsGoScYdRP33GLFYFhLP-2x5t0SdGeg8biksueC4dNRiztKddoPG1tr~~sDkBrwlqeYpAOlfoVDh9bhKWpWEiTEOIQBFKot54xWyZE-02u9V3GpXT5lr4Cu66qiDbduDGZTDqotkxOs37Mi153guxmCK1cylTNuxEOtWLxLEPmW93t~74zl0MsWPbI8rC2ba1Ku50pfRgjhd~SEvGi9NoNajWU7UgDgppXr3fOsa45bVR1ep6ELQinmyLtzWIL6PWoJhisLNL-q-c0z2CSO0MiTJ-cEnmyUzxhtK1oB3fvicS-Tup~g6TdkEy-KFgpt-EH0WhPzWSnPdvg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053656&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig3.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Total galaxy SFR against stellar mass for the lensed arcs for which we are able to derive stellar masses, in comparison with other high-redshift kinematic studies. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines indicate the star-forming galaxy \u2018main sequence\u2019 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00, 1 and 2.5 (Whitaker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Comparison data are from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and the grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS points. The lensed arcs, as well as the WiggleZ and SHiZELS samples, are similar to <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01 main-sequence star-forming galaxies, though the lensed arcs probe the lower mass end of the relation. The SINS AO sample covers higher specific SFRs, similar to the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.5 star-forming main sequence.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=3X5ZkpHJ4XSd-44jcOk4SEhW0By70j1n~YvVEXyPEZF0-dXdUzSD~MNgnUnEDM1u4eYDdY0RZRsenBj6asd-Pe5naRGsb~XyETmFME-kgGVEy3pTEk8HYGXjUTeYY6O8a5CUfZdSVeJVFM8ZglUfcywQC6oYrlswP-mmFo3o2wVgEsmVyoSYDZcPdHQhaV96l~HIy7dYDc1YzpKNK5KJvYVMG0lNrzB~VqbixPSnmN90h7O9tr1-YTjVVQQqm-HEQpM8bahnpJmad8kslJqzdPDQ96RgkZCCSqbIthUbmEF3bwDSfQSzDjoyxjWjimOuZUfjtf9soqj1HzLvpHVtOQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Total galaxy SFR against stellar mass for the lensed arcs for which we are able to derive stellar masses, in comparison with other high-redshift kinematic studies. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines indicate the star-forming galaxy \u2018main sequence\u2019 at z\u00a0=\u00a00, 1 and 2.5 (Whitaker et\u00a0al. 2012). Comparison data are from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012a), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. 2013), and the grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS points. The lensed arcs, as well as the WiggleZ and SHiZELS samples, are similar to z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01 main-sequence star-forming galaxies, though the lensed arcs probe the lower mass end of the relation. The SINS AO sample covers higher specific SFRs, similar to the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.5 star-forming main sequence.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig3.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053656/stv686fig3.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig3.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053656\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=1c6wQTsjVsGoScYdRP33GLFYFhLP-2x5t0SdGeg8biksueC4dNRiztKddoPG1tr~~sDkBrwlqeYpAOlfoVDh9bhKWpWEiTEOIQBFKot54xWyZE-02u9V3GpXT5lr4Cu66qiDbduDGZTDqotkxOs37Mi153guxmCK1cylTNuxEOtWLxLEPmW93t~74zl0MsWPbI8rC2ba1Ku50pfRgjhd~SEvGi9NoNajWU7UgDgppXr3fOsa45bVR1ep6ELQinmyLtzWIL6PWoJhisLNL-q-c0z2CSO0MiTJ-cEnmyUzxhtK1oB3fvicS-Tup~g6TdkEy-KFgpt-EH0WhPzWSnPdvg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053656&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig3.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Total galaxy SFR against stellar mass for the lensed arcs for which we are able to derive stellar masses, in comparison with other high-redshift kinematic studies. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines indicate the star-forming galaxy \u2018main sequence\u2019 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00, 1 and 2.5 (Whitaker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Comparison data are from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and the grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS points. The lensed arcs, as well as the WiggleZ and SHiZELS samples, are similar to <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01 main-sequence star-forming galaxies, though the lensed arcs probe the lower mass end of the relation. The SINS AO sample covers higher specific SFRs, similar to the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.5 star-forming main sequence.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17053657 id=\"17053657\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 RESULTS AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053658 id=\"17053658\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Dynamics</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17053659 id=\"17053659\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Dynamical properties of the sample</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From our best estimates of kinematic classification given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, we estimate that 10/17(59\u2009per\u2009cent) of the combined lensed sample are rotating discs, 5/17(29\u2009per\u2009cent) are probable mergers, and the remaining two are undetermined. The merger fraction in our sample is very close to those in unlensed surveys, typically 1/3, but we find a higher fraction of rotating systems, which typically make up 33\u201344\u2009per\u2009cent of other samples (F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Epinat et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). While the merger classification adopted is relatively insensitive to spatial resolution, it is likely that many of the galaxies classed as \u2018dispersion-dominated\u2019 in unlensed studies would present with velocity gradients given higher spatial resolution. For example, Newman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) found that when the same 34 galaxies observed in seeing-limited conditions were re-observed with adaptive optics, the fraction classified as dispersion-dominated fell from 41 to 6\u20139\u2009per\u2009cent. The two galaxies we classify as undetermined are A1835-arc7.1 and MS1621-system1. The former lies on the critical line so it is possible that we have not observed the whole velocity gradient in this source. Alternatively, the turnover in the rotation curves of these galaxies might be missed due to the presence of a low-surface-brightness disc.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The quantity <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 is a measure of the rotational support in a system. Galaxies exist on a continuum in <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3; they all have some degree of rotation, but those with low <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 values have a larger fraction of their kinematic support from random motion rather than ordered rotation. Generally, a simple cut is applied, where galaxies with <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.4 are considered rotating systems (F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Of our combined sample, only A1835-arc7.1 falls beneath this cut, with <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3\u00a0=\u00a00.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2. However, as discussed above, we may not have observed the full velocity gradient in this galaxy. Three of the galaxies that appear to be interactions or mergers \u2013 A1413-arc2.1a, A1413-arc2.1b and RXJ1720-arc1.1+1.2 \u2013 all have marginal <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 within 1\u03c3 of the boundary between rotation-dominated and dispersion-dominated systems. The remaining possible merger \u2013 MS1621 \u2013 has high <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3\u00a0=\u00a03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, which could be due to a velocity difference between two merging components.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In non-lensed galaxies observed with adaptive optics, Newman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) found a correlation between <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 and the half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>. This was suggested to be due to a relationship between <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, with larger galaxies having higher rotation velocities. We add our sample to these relationships in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. As gravitational lensing allows us to observe intrinsically smaller galaxies, we are able to extend these relations to smaller sizes, and we find much more scatter than in the unlensed systems, with a Spearman rank correlation coefficient of \u03c1\u00a0=\u00a00.61 (where \u03c1\u00a0=\u00a00 indicates no correlation, and \u03c1\u00a0=\u00a01 implies perfect correlation).</p>                        <a id=\"17053663\" scrollto-destination=\"17053663\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=M-esqedA8sxdmfQ5teZK5UkcR9ypC7OamCCYxal6ijGrlUxthmj5Rpows2VisyAH2E9~ZgSyH8KKeYRKNcXjDJWDMucXyfPneqlgI9uYrnmZ--XLHa~pSXTrQttXUmDoVq~I-X52WtMnorm9XE872Z2c3bCqvwSmySSTyh1aaYgfCzbEGMXY1Rk~eKg-XP2iwmo6bUKmlRCJ2GgpXAx1gaRKud4dup2ysS5q1-c-eV1DAfkKWfSN5M-KaRvKYABWVIVlKgmAFxIVZivxthtwGIM0ku8gkvBESepWcyQHUKq762S4uLenBUr2CQEDORWcZbcEm5KubMCeDKy3Pwa8lA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: relation between rotational velocity and half-light radius. Right: vrot/\u03c3 against half-light radius. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift on the same scale in both plots, with filled symbols representing those galaxies identified as discs, and unfilled symbols mergers or undetermined systems. Comparison samples are included from the high-z lensed sources of Jones et\u00a0al. (2010a), and the unlensed high-z IFU surveys SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012a), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. 2013). The grey crosses indicate the average error on the SINS points. The dashed line is the fit to the SINS data from Newman et\u00a0al. (2013). The intrinsically smaller lensed galaxies extend the non-lensed samples to smaller sizes, but the correlation is weaker.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig4.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053663/stv686fig4.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig4.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053663\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=kgQVaC~vnvxdN0N3Wl1qT-dmpDZHhmK~upUUvrzv-uCN~eU9RXs6ddCaoW3rzFOYjbvmYBdpYENh6LOvvXWdlVYt1Vt0MO957Ozx~sxPxyC4aCPi6SU2jiaFjY5F3d3z3ejaNfCUknor7sJhkFU9PhoajK-1DeFS7u3wa1b10lq1nVIHvqpUOF733S-Z8GEk8M7KOHFYXYbLffaepaFnx-M~fjMvIy6X2PXILmFrznEnHO6aT~4kUmQIKKbJNKYhdqqYlo80MG01vhuSfSYOlomeyJqYsCTAVkuuSQTY5k9xtCAtZgz0CVGkdoDW1UbauyTWz4o9HA2tQTbsvP29GA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053663&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig4.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: relation between rotational velocity and half-light radius. Right: <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 against half-light radius. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift on the same scale in both plots, with filled symbols representing those galaxies identified as discs, and unfilled symbols mergers or undetermined systems. Comparison samples are included from the high-<em>z</em> lensed sources of Jones et\u00a0al.
