Eye-1\u00a0</td><td>600\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0100\u00a0</td><td>25.\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06.\u00a0</td><td>41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a015\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cosmic Eye-2\u00a0</td><td>500\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0100\u00a0</td><td>12.\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a014\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> All quantities are corrected for lensing where appropriate. (a): the clump radius is calculated as described in the text, using the area enclosed by an isophote and assuming circular symmetry. The error bar encompasses an alternative definition using the FWHM of the clump emission line profile. (b): SFR is calculated from the total H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 flux enclosed in the isophote and is corrected for extinction. (c): the velocity dispersion, \u03c3, is the mean local value within the clump and is deconvolved for the local velocity gradient.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/17053686\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) found that the clumps in high-redshift lensed galaxies had surface brightnesses that are higher than those of local H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions by up to 100\u00a0times. Such intense star-forming regions are found locally in merging systems such as the Antennae (Bastian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), but appeared to be ubiquitous in isolated discs at high-<em>z</em>. Similar results were found at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and in kpc-scale clumps from unlensed sources (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>; Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). To investigate the origin of these high-surface brightness clumps, Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) observed 57 clumps in eight galaxies with H\u03b1 narrow-band imaging, and demonstrated that their surface brightnesses evolve with redshift. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we expand on this relation adding our new clumps. We note that one galaxy \u2013 MACS1149-arcA1.1 \u2013 is included in both the current IFU sample and the narrow-band imaging sample. Only one clump (the galaxy bulge) was observed in the narrow-band sample, and we confirm that its luminosity is consistent with the previous observation within the measurement errors.</p>                        <a id=\"17053688\" scrollto-destination=\"17053688\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=WCABAewP0EswEUKE9-eLE2s8qB30KjSvdfLkvVL122nT~gaby9yh5b1sM0p5mg2jY0jBKkZrE1ArY23zyrYD3E7iOFZaBsL1NHt3mYmT6W2VOi4dTtD9o9cMntepKwvppqImGbodDSkHO-ujcBdEkM~J~nZy4zkNDfadjXTg6U2NQplLUJt9cjGiBACTyz-MEMHfAw4dslAGdAANxAXwVKR88OLDaj~K9kaDkO5wdaLLAFWWTqS5MP84n-Ysw~Ei8moTLtHwbh5LHYBKa~zyJMGuuz3VitzbAuQmg2A4OhIlXhU6JbtncSEiOlitKwaB4bvaZFQHR5OLJ3HMD7DEFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relation between SFR in clumps and their sizes. The z\u00a0=\u00a00 sample from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. 2003) and the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20131.5 lensed arcs from Livermore et\u00a0al. (2012a) are extracted from H\u03b1 narrow-band imaging. We also show the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2007, 2009) and the unlensed high-z samples from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012b) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2012) for comparison. The clumps from our sample of lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines are contours of constant surface brightness with the zero-points fit in four redshift bins. We find evolution in this zero-point such that high-redshift galaxies host clumps of higher surface brightnesses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig8.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053688/stv686fig8.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig8.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053688\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=s2WJv2m9n~fCnjun7t-4tZCuO8j29ug7K8dP0NRmaoLZJ5zTZnivL4e9ZiLhvYpLd7aAMZ49F4V3tLBhOm4DOzmb2Cs6kYCP9XJaJWzkGu1qbxJAqLOs3dZBkDMOLM-3q1DXj1QfoC7m9~bfA5DFNYkl4l2ZE~FOuGSxXk2P87cqmQ5tM619~28xUkdU-v2U9o-rpPBGncCOE0G1YaemU9tzM30SEUb-wjXzhT8x7UBawTxwlsm~Kq6WZPdovB3ULSSjm9kZ3N1i6~LEvydzhO7Mn6WOCGqJTYmxHve0hC7jBOhebLsINetCkAEZlZ63WUQaI42dv2ai1NNu0R5UrQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053688&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig8.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relation between SFR in clumps and their sizes. The <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 sample from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20131.5 lensed arcs from Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) are extracted from H\u03b1 narrow-band imaging. We also show the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and the unlensed high-<em>z</em> samples from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) for comparison. The clumps from our sample of lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines are contours of constant surface brightness with the zero-points fit in four redshift bins. We find evolution in this zero-point such that high-redshift galaxies host clumps of higher surface brightnesses.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=WCABAewP0EswEUKE9-eLE2s8qB30KjSvdfLkvVL122nT~gaby9yh5b1sM0p5mg2jY0jBKkZrE1ArY23zyrYD3E7iOFZaBsL1NHt3mYmT6W2VOi4dTtD9o9cMntepKwvppqImGbodDSkHO-ujcBdEkM~J~nZy4zkNDfadjXTg6U2NQplLUJt9cjGiBACTyz-MEMHfAw4dslAGdAANxAXwVKR88OLDaj~K9kaDkO5wdaLLAFWWTqS5MP84n-Ysw~Ei8moTLtHwbh5LHYBKa~zyJMGuuz3VitzbAuQmg2A4OhIlXhU6JbtncSEiOlitKwaB4bvaZFQHR5OLJ3HMD7DEFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relation between SFR in clumps and their sizes. The z\u00a0=\u00a00 sample from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. 2003) and the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20131.5 lensed arcs from Livermore et\u00a0al. (2012a) are extracted from H\u03b1 narrow-band imaging. We also show the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2007, 2009) and the unlensed high-z samples from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012b) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2012) for comparison. The clumps from our sample of lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines are contours of constant surface brightness with the zero-points fit in four redshift bins. We find evolution in this zero-point such that high-redshift galaxies host clumps of higher surface brightnesses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig8.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053688/stv686fig8.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig8.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053688\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=s2WJv2m9n~fCnjun7t-4tZCuO8j29ug7K8dP0NRmaoLZJ5zTZnivL4e9ZiLhvYpLd7aAMZ49F4V3tLBhOm4DOzmb2Cs6kYCP9XJaJWzkGu1qbxJAqLOs3dZBkDMOLM-3q1DXj1QfoC7m9~bfA5DFNYkl4l2ZE~FOuGSxXk2P87cqmQ5tM619~28xUkdU-v2U9o-rpPBGncCOE0G1YaemU9tzM30SEUb-wjXzhT8x7UBawTxwlsm~Kq6WZPdovB3ULSSjm9kZ3N1i6~LEvydzhO7Mn6WOCGqJTYmxHve0hC7jBOhebLsINetCkAEZlZ63WUQaI42dv2ai1NNu0R5UrQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053688&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig8.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relation between SFR in clumps and their sizes. The <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 sample from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20131.5 lensed arcs from Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) are extracted from H\u03b1 narrow-band imaging. We also show the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and the unlensed high-<em>z</em> samples from SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) for comparison. The clumps from our sample of lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift. The dashed lines are contours of constant surface brightness with the zero-points fit in four redshift bins. We find evolution in this zero-point such that high-redshift galaxies host clumps of higher surface brightnesses.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">With the new data, the evolution in clump surface brightnesses is confirmed and extended out to <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03. We show the mean surface brightness, \u03a3<sub>clump</sub>, in four redshift bins in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. The best fit to the redshift evolution of the clump surface brightness is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\log \\left(\\frac{\\Sigma _{\\rm clump}}{{\\rm M}_{{\\odot }}\\,{\\rm yr}^{-1}\\,{\\rm kpc}^{-2}}\\right) = \\left( 3.5 \\pm 0.5 \\right) \\log \\left( 1 + z\\right) - \\left( 1.7 \\pm 0.2 \\right).\\nonumber\\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Clearly, there is a selection effect involved, as we would not observe low-surface-brightness clumps in the high-<em>z</em> galaxies. However, there appears to be evolution in the properties of the brightest clumps, as these are not seen in isolated local galaxies but seem to be ubiquitous at high redshift. We will discuss this further in the context of the clump luminosity function along with implications of this evolution in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The IFU data of our current sample allow us to add the extra dimension of velocity dispersion, \u03c3, to this analysis. If the clumps are gravitationally bound, they should follow a relation of the form <em>L</em>\u2009\u221d\u2009\u03c3<sup>4</sup> (Terlevich &amp; Melnick <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>). However, not all studies of local star-forming regions have found this relation; Arsenault et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>) found that it applied only to the brightest, \u2018first-ranked\u2019 regions in galaxies, with no <em>L</em>\u2013\u03c3 or <em>r</em>\u2013\u03c3 relation applying to their entire sample. Others have found a shallower <em>L</em>\u2013\u03c3 relation indicative of density-bounded regions, where only a fraction of the ionizing photons are able to escape (Rozas, Sabalisck &amp; Beckman <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Rozas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). It is not clear that clumps should be expected to be virialized; indeed, giant molecular clouds locally are not necessarily gravitationally bound (Dobbs, Burkert &amp; Pringle <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we plot \u03c3 as a function of both the clump size and luminosity. As a guide, we overlay the relations found by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\log \\left( \\frac{r}{\\rm {kpc}} \\right) = \\left( 1.01 \\pm 0.08 \\right) \\log \\left( \\frac{\\sigma }{\\rm {km\\,s}^{-1}} \\right) + \\left( 0.8 \\pm 0.1 \\right)\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\log \\left( \\frac{L}{\\rm {erg\\,s}^{-1}} \\right) = \\left(3.81 \\pm 0.29 \\right) \\log \\left( \\frac{\\sigma }{\\rm {km\\,s}^{-1}}\\right) + \\left( 34.7 \\pm 0.4 \\right).\\nonumber\\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div></div>                        <a id=\"17053693\" scrollto-destination=\"17053693\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=dtJkGc0xaQdZp2zjduhNTZ91h8r-h~C7neHmaxy-Eapcdlt0mPqHbcPg8XjurZJJYRoSyhlHhzlr2WORqSb1UVt-dYDYuIfh9VV~zRStJ5Ga-qkcaXzD4m-MnAHqfRdOC01Fp3WrX-1nD6tRmywHMjbWC0s6cFjMl6SSNwACvxUikCWy9VRZhCB3hp~hiNQc6kohAQnVKSGQMpCqe77Z7dLp0UlUvt1e9kT-GVtbH0SwhvCwGH-FUyw2Ej7D540cKrflgeWQ3ld-JXlAhvIXqxq4pMkjh7jLSi6C5Antpg8f9eLFK3LzyeonBMaW-cA295Wh1fw6sydRkoSGgzmlbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Velocity dispersion, \u03c3, of star-forming clumps, as a function of clump size (left) and H\u03b1 luminosity (right). Clumps from the local Universe are taken from Terlevich &amp; Melnick (1981), Arsenault, Roy &amp; Boulesteix (1990), Bordalo &amp; Telles (2011), Fuentes-Masip et\u00a0al. (2000) and Rozas et\u00a0al. (2006). The high-redshift comparison samples are from the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2007) and Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2009) (with LH\u03b1 estimated from the [O\u2009ii]-derived SFRs), and the unlensed SINS (Genzel et\u00a0al. 2011), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2012) and SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012b) surveys. The shaded region shows the best fits from Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2012b), the dashed line is the best-fitting LH\u03b1\u2013\u03c3 relation from Rozas et\u00a0al. (2006), and the dotted line indicates the estimated resolution limit (determined as described in the text). The addition of lensed galaxies extends the high-z samples to smaller sizes and lower luminosities while \u03c3 is similar to the unlensed samples. Although partially an effect of the spectral resolution limit, we find an excess of clumps with high resolved \u03c3 for their sizes and luminosities.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig9.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053693/stv686fig9.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig9.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053693\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=ga2etQ7c2Zb1TNFAXdn1ZQTGBaFDKqnBqhA9zVvxjLVX-m1vHY36yRZKopkByKKAzC2VQ--S4yW2c202-JH6pntIwBo8hue1I4AZt9FnrnU8bceARE9WcO7sXeRFISp6AnnjaDeViuLgo9CyrSnJZtDPd0pLYN8DLsQJ7yLeoemvCgma~z-4iYy8N~3NU3v7WxHU5hUootiN--0lByBh518WVr8cpAGpCHqmOecxMu7Q91j7BhUJZqiJG3~P1nS91FsCPeEzyxCVlmvseSv0l9qZKzUpkVc8xl~5wp6TtW6RBe1q7uOt-T2zeozqIY5CadQ-Ht41sRyQGJJ5pTs3Ag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053693&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig9.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Velocity dispersion, \u03c3, of star-forming clumps, as a function of clump size (left) and H\u03b1 luminosity (right). Clumps from the local Universe are taken from Terlevich &amp; Melnick (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>), Arsenault, Roy &amp; Boulesteix (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>), Bordalo &amp; Telles (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Fuentes-Masip et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) and Rozas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The high-redshift comparison samples are from the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) (with <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub> estimated from the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-derived SFRs), and the unlensed SINS (Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>) surveys. The shaded region shows the best fits from Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>), the dashed line is the best-fitting <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub>\u2013\u03c3 relation from Rozas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and the dotted line indicates the estimated resolution limit (determined as described in the text). The addition of lensed galaxies extends the high-<em>z</em> samples to smaller sizes and lower luminosities while \u03c3 is similar to the unlensed samples. Although partially an effect of the spectral resolution limit, we find an excess of clumps with high resolved \u03c3 for their sizes and luminosities.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=dtJkGc0xaQdZp2zjduhNTZ91h8r-h~C7neHmaxy-Eapcdlt0mPqHbcPg8XjurZJJYRoSyhlHhzlr2WORqSb1UVt-dYDYuIfh9VV~zRStJ5Ga-qkcaXzD4m-MnAHqfRdOC01Fp3WrX-1nD6tRmywHMjbWC0s6cFjMl6SSNwACvxUikCWy9VRZhCB3hp~hiNQc6kohAQnVKSGQMpCqe77Z7dLp0UlUvt1e9kT-GVtbH0SwhvCwGH-FUyw2Ej7D540cKrflgeWQ3ld-JXlAhvIXqxq4pMkjh7jLSi6C5Antpg8f9eLFK3LzyeonBMaW-cA295Wh1fw6sydRkoSGgzmlbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Velocity dispersion, \u03c3, of star-forming clumps, as a function of clump size (left) and H\u03b1 luminosity (right). Clumps from the local Universe are taken from Terlevich &amp; Melnick (1981), Arsenault, Roy &amp; Boulesteix (1990), Bordalo &amp; Telles (2011), Fuentes-Masip et\u00a0al. (2000) and Rozas et\u00a0al. (2006). The high-redshift comparison samples are from the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2007) and Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2009) (with LH\u03b1 estimated from the [O\u2009ii]-derived SFRs), and the unlensed SINS (Genzel et\u00a0al. 2011), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2012) and SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012b) surveys. The shaded region shows the best fits from Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2012b), the dashed line is the best-fitting LH\u03b1\u2013\u03c3 relation from Rozas et\u00a0al. (2006), and the dotted line indicates the estimated resolution limit (determined as described in the text). The addition of lensed galaxies extends the high-z samples to smaller sizes and lower luminosities while \u03c3 is similar to the unlensed samples. Although partially an effect of the spectral resolution limit, we find an excess of clumps with high resolved \u03c3 for their sizes and luminosities.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig9.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053693/stv686fig9.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig9.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053693\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=ga2etQ7c2Zb1TNFAXdn1ZQTGBaFDKqnBqhA9zVvxjLVX-m1vHY36yRZKopkByKKAzC2VQ--S4yW2c202-JH6pntIwBo8hue1I4AZt9FnrnU8bceARE9WcO7sXeRFISp6AnnjaDeViuLgo9CyrSnJZtDPd0pLYN8DLsQJ7yLeoemvCgma~z-4iYy8N~3NU3v7WxHU5hUootiN--0lByBh518WVr8cpAGpCHqmOecxMu7Q91j7BhUJZqiJG3~P1nS91FsCPeEzyxCVlmvseSv0l9qZKzUpkVc8xl~5wp6TtW6RBe1q7uOt-T2zeozqIY5CadQ-Ht41sRyQGJJ5pTs3Ag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053693&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig9.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Velocity dispersion, \u03c3, of star-forming clumps, as a function of clump size (left) and H\u03b1 luminosity (right). Clumps from the local Universe are taken from Terlevich &amp; Melnick (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>), Arsenault, Roy &amp; Boulesteix (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>), Bordalo &amp; Telles (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Fuentes-Masip et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) and Rozas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The high-redshift comparison samples are from the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) (with <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub> estimated from the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-derived SFRs), and the unlensed SINS (Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>) surveys. The shaded region shows the best fits from Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>), the dashed line is the best-fitting <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub>\u2013\u03c3 relation from Rozas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and the dotted line indicates the estimated resolution limit (determined as described in the text). The addition of lensed galaxies extends the high-<em>z</em> samples to smaller sizes and lower luminosities while \u03c3 is similar to the unlensed samples. Although partially an effect of the spectral resolution limit, we find an excess of clumps with high resolved \u03c3 for their sizes and luminosities.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although our data scatter around these relations, we do not find any correlation between \u03c3 in our clumps and either <em>r</em> or <em>L</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We first consider whether this is an effect of spectral resolution. We deconvolve \u03c3 for the instrumental resolution as measured from sky emission lines, but there is some lower limit at which we will not be able to measure the broadening of the line. To test where this limit is, we construct a set of 1000 Gaussian emission lines with varying widths of &lt;100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and add noise so that the final S/N = 5 (this gives us a conservative estimate, as S/N &gt; 5 is the constraint we set to detect an emission line). We then convolve the resulting spectrum with the instrumental resolution, and apply the same emission line fitting routine used on the data to recover the line properties. We find that we consistently recover the input line width to within 20\u2009per\u2009cent at \u03c3\u00a0&gt;\u00a053\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We show this line on Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The clumps that lie close to this line may be affected by the resolution limit; however, there remains an excess of clumps at high \u03c3 that are well-resolved and lie above the expected relations. It therefore appears that the clumps are not necessarily virialized, and the observed \u03c3 may contain contributions from a range of processes including gravitational instabilities and star formation feedback. A further possible contribution to the high \u03c3 values could come from the superposition of multiple clumps along the line of sight. This is an additional source of uncertainty in all values derived from clumps, and motivates studies with higher spectral resolution so that any such multiple clumps can be kinematically separated.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17053697 id=\"17053697\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053698 id=\"17053698\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Clump formation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) demonstrated that an effective means of quantifying the \u2018clumpiness\u2019 of a galaxy is the clump luminosity function. The luminosity function can be described by a Schechter function with a cut-off at some maximum luminosity <em>L</em><sub>0</sub>, which describes the brightest clumps. The presence of more bright clumps in a galaxy causes it to appear as \u2018clumpy.\u2019 Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) showed that <em>L</em><sub>0</sub> increases with redshift, giving rise to the appearance of more clumpy galaxies at high redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show the luminosity functions in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> with the new data added. We account for the varying surface brightness limits of the observations by normalizing each bin by the number of galaxies in which we should be able to identify clumps of that luminosity, and the error bars represent the Poisson error from counting clumps. The <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 bin combines the two <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 galaxies from the current sample with the seven galaxies from the Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) narrow-band imaging sample (MACS1149-arcA1.1 is removed from the latter as it is duplicated in the current sample), and the <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03 bin includes the two lensed <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05 galaxies of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"17053701\" scrollto-destination=\"17053701\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=ychHoi9qWcTvxn0V2VIIerP9e0R-C8M40L8TH9UY18m82TG--2fTM92uef04zyZ5oIQfijJqaMndxJqdhgrJXBR0oLtk-Eo1IqtDmIy-odUpvItVUcsk9mizO85w7HBm6Mkmyni651Rtrd87Fmcrjd4hF2ZiHwaqrpNTgA2niPmTfba~p1Ucqw8c~G~-X1w7PT62FlbtvqItnd7PUmvGCia-fPu7T59K8kbBlYuSyYtDyb6kMD7Y~7~eV3xcHIitLPKuaf0ilUQGhSMqdE9lTQes9DCqhxYdKMR1i1eb4gJY604NRSMWqeXc5n4frNOPk2yLIub7Z43Fv0OVwAQKuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative clump luminosity functions. The z\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. 2003), with clumps extracted by Livermore et\u00a0al. (2012a). The z\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 bin includes the narrow-band imaging sample of Livermore et\u00a0al. (2012a) combined with the two z\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 galaxies from this work. Each luminosity bin is normalized by the number of galaxies contributing to that bin, accounting for variations in the depth of observations as described in the text. The dashed lines are Schechter function fits, where the z\u00a0=\u00a00 fit is from the simulations of Hopkins, Quataert &amp; Murray (2012), and we keep the same normalization but allow the cut-off to vary to fit the high-redshift data. We find that this cut-off evolves with redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig10.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053701/stv686fig10.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig10.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053701\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=qW6zQEQGa6-LiiatGCulF9S5sJPzJBXgGSmnoDzZpVhzcX9Xe4ZNrAs1WsqXA0AfRfSHoPykq74JVyJ6ADp6GU3Kto4zIEJBQ1xL8pZy2eiHGfoRJC7i~nLJFxRVlUYff0JdXqfbvMBf4ckFx-V2MK3WtOGq6B6-P8DpGd1~haM14n0yqWTMe1w8kAOwdegC9-MQs5qu2igVKfAbXgcSoFZuNrYelHXk8nmTfTI2IxuEcrCvcP0pDC8Ec5FhX9Thn2~8Hfw-xg3cE~tJ0lKWLO-e4NDXIPNSEOmrn0I2~n1IiiyRyAyd5T0LKVtHjljS0YhmcbRSPrT35523cclGyA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053701&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig10.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative clump luminosity functions. The <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), with clumps extracted by Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). The <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 bin includes the narrow-band imaging sample of Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) combined with the two <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 galaxies from this work. Each luminosity bin is normalized by the number of galaxies contributing to that bin, accounting for variations in the depth of observations as described in the text. The dashed lines are Schechter function fits, where the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 fit is from the simulations of Hopkins, Quataert &amp; Murray (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and we keep the same normalization but allow the cut-off to vary to fit the high-redshift data. We find that this cut-off evolves with redshift.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=ychHoi9qWcTvxn0V2VIIerP9e0R-C8M40L8TH9UY18m82TG--2fTM92uef04zyZ5oIQfijJqaMndxJqdhgrJXBR0oLtk-Eo1IqtDmIy-odUpvItVUcsk9mizO85w7HBm6Mkmyni651Rtrd87Fmcrjd4hF2ZiHwaqrpNTgA2niPmTfba~p1Ucqw8c~G~-X1w7PT62FlbtvqItnd7PUmvGCia-fPu7T59K8kbBlYuSyYtDyb6kMD7Y~7~eV3xcHIitLPKuaf0ilUQGhSMqdE9lTQes9DCqhxYdKMR1i1eb4gJY604NRSMWqeXc5n4frNOPk2yLIub7Z43Fv0OVwAQKuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative clump luminosity functions. The z\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. 2003), with clumps extracted by Livermore et\u00a0al. (2012a). The z\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 bin includes the narrow-band imaging sample of Livermore et\u00a0al. (2012a) combined with the two z\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 galaxies from this work. Each luminosity bin is normalized by the number of galaxies contributing to that bin, accounting for variations in the depth of observations as described in the text. The dashed lines are Schechter function fits, where the z\u00a0=\u00a00 fit is from the simulations of Hopkins, Quataert &amp; Murray (2012), and we keep the same normalization but allow the cut-off to vary to fit the high-redshift data. We find that this cut-off evolves with redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig10.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053701/stv686fig10.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig10.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053701\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=qW6zQEQGa6-LiiatGCulF9S5sJPzJBXgGSmnoDzZpVhzcX9Xe4ZNrAs1WsqXA0AfRfSHoPykq74JVyJ6ADp6GU3Kto4zIEJBQ1xL8pZy2eiHGfoRJC7i~nLJFxRVlUYff0JdXqfbvMBf4ckFx-V2MK3WtOGq6B6-P8DpGd1~haM14n0yqWTMe1w8kAOwdegC9-MQs5qu2igVKfAbXgcSoFZuNrYelHXk8nmTfTI2IxuEcrCvcP0pDC8Ec5FhX9Thn2~8Hfw-xg3cE~tJ0lKWLO-e4NDXIPNSEOmrn0I2~n1IiiyRyAyd5T0LKVtHjljS0YhmcbRSPrT35523cclGyA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053701&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig10.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative clump luminosity functions. The <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from the SINGS survey (Kennicutt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), with clumps extracted by Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). The <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 bin includes the narrow-band imaging sample of Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) combined with the two <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 galaxies from this work. Each luminosity bin is normalized by the number of galaxies contributing to that bin, accounting for variations in the depth of observations as described in the text. The dashed lines are Schechter function fits, where the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 fit is from the simulations of Hopkins, Quataert &amp; Murray (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and we keep the same normalization but allow the cut-off to vary to fit the high-redshift data. We find that this cut-off evolves with redshift.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To each redshift bin, we fit a Schechter function of the form <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nN \\left( &gt;L \\right) = N_0 \\left( \\frac{L}{L_0} \\right)^{\\alpha } \\exp \\left( \\frac{-L}{L_0} \\right),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>where the power-law slope is fixed to \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a0\u22120.75 from Hopkins et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We do not attempt to fit the faint-end slope as the sharp turnovers evident in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> are likely due to incompleteness and small number statistics in the faintest clumps. The normalization <em>N</em><sub>0</sub> is arbitrary, so we fit <em>N</em><sub>0</sub> to the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 data. We then keep <em>N</em><sub>0</sub> and \u03b1 fixed while allowing the cut-off <em>L</em><sub>0</sub> to vary, and we find the best-fitting <em>L</em><sub>0</sub> for each bin with a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization procedure. The best fits are <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\frac{L_0}{\\rm {erg\\,s}^{-1}} = \\left\\lbrace \\begin{array}{@{}l@{\\quad }l@{}}2.5^{+1.8}_{-1.2} \\times 10^{41}, &amp;z = 0 \\\\\r\n 4.0^{+0.7}_{-0.7} \\times 10^{41}, &amp;1 &lt; z &lt; 1.5 \\\\\r\n 4^{+3}_{-3} \\times 10^{42}, &amp;1.5 &lt; z &lt; 3 \\\\\r\n 1.3^{+0.9}_{-0.8} \\times 10^{43}, &amp;z &gt; 3 \\end{array}\\right.,\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>where the errors are estimated using a bootstrap method.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We therefore find that the cut-off of the clump luminosity function evolves with redshift, such that high-redshift galaxies have more high-luminosity clumps. The best fit to the redshift evolution of <em>L</em><sub>0</sub> is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\log \\left(\\frac{L_0}{{\\rm erg\\,s}^{-1}}\\right) = \\left( 2.0 \\pm 0.7 \\right) \\log \\left( 1 + z \\right) + \\left( 41.0 \\pm 0.2 \\right).\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In combination with the evolution in clump surface brightness discussed in the previous section, it follows that high-redshift galaxies tend to have a higher number of bright, high surface-brightness star-forming clumps, which come to dominate the galaxy morphology and therefore give rise to the population of \u2018clumpy\u2019 galaxies seen at high redshift.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) suggest that the cause of these bright clumps is a combination of high gas fractions at high redshift and the evolving galaxy dynamics. Briefly, the argument is based on the assumption that clumps form in marginally stable discs described by a Toomre (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>) parameter <em>Q</em> where <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nQ = \\frac{\\kappa \\sigma _{\\rm t}(R)}{\\pi G \\Sigma _0} \\approx 1,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(10)</span></div>for epicyclic frequency <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa \\approx \\sqrt{2}v/r$|</span> and velocity <em>v</em> at galactocentric radius <em>r</em>. Hopkins et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) argued that star-forming galaxies tend to self-regulate to maintain <em>Q</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01; instabilities cause the gas to collapse to form stars, while feedback from the star formation stabilises the disc.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The mass required for collapse on a scale <em>R</em> is the Jeans mass, <em>M</em><sub>J</sub>, given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ11\" content-id=\"equ11\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nM_{\\rm J} = \\frac{3R}{2G}\\sigma .\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(11)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">If <em>M</em><sub>J</sub> is related to the maximum mass of clumps in a galaxy, <em>M</em><sub>0</sub> (i.e. the cut-off of the mass function), then Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) showed that combining equations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ10\"></span><a href=\"#equ10\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">10</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ11\"></span><a href=\"#equ11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">11</a>) with an assumed turbulent power spectrum gives <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ12\" content-id=\"equ12\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nM_0 = \\frac{3 \\pi ^3 G^2}{2} \\frac{\\Sigma _0^3}{\\kappa ^4}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(12)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Thus, <em>M</em><sub>0</sub> depends on the disc surface density and epicyclic frequency. To relate this predicted mass to the observable <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub>, we use an empirical relation between the H\u03b1-derived SFR and mass of local molecular clouds, SFR(M<sub>\u2299</sub>yr<sup>\u22121</sup>)\u00a0=\u00a04.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.6\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22128</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Lada, Lombardi &amp; Alves <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This relation is valid for high-density gas, and thus appropriate for star-forming clumps, and is consistent with the independently derived SFRs and gas masses of star-forming clumps reported in a lensed <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.3 galaxy by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Adopting this conversion results in cut-off masses, <em>M</em><sub>0</sub>, from our clump luminosity functions of <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\frac{M_0}{\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}} = \\left\\lbrace \\begin{array}{@{}l@{\\quad }l@{}}4^{+3}_{-2} \\times 10^{7}, &amp;z = 0 \\\\\r\n 1.0^{+0.2}_{-0.2} \\times 10^{8}, &amp;1 &lt; z &lt; 1.5 \\\\\r\n 9^{+7}_{-7} \\times 10^{8}, &amp;1.5 &lt; z &lt; 3 \\\\\r\n 3^{+2}_{-2} \\times 10^{9}, &amp;z &gt; 3 \\end{array}\\right..\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We can also relate the SFR surface density, \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub>, of clumps to the disc surface density, \u03a3<sub>0</sub>, using the Kennicutt\u2013Schmidt law. The relationship between the surface density of gas, \u03a3<sub>gas</sub>, and \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub> found by Kennicutt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998b</a>) is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ13\" content-id=\"equ13\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\frac{\\Sigma _{\\rm SFR}}{\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}\\,\\rm {yr}^{-1}\\rm {kpc}^{-2}} = A \\left( \\frac{\\Sigma _{\\rm g}}{\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}\\rm {pc}^{-2}}\\right) ^{n},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(13)</span></div>where <em>A</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> and <em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15. The disc surface density \u03a3<sub>0</sub> is a combination of gas and stars (\u03a3<sub>g</sub> and \u03a3<sub>*</sub>, respectively), which contribute differently to the disc stability. Following Rafikov (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>), we use <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ14\" content-id=\"equ14\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\Sigma _0 = \\Sigma _{\\rm {g}} + \\left( \\frac{2}{1 + f_{\\sigma }^2} \\right)\\Sigma _{\\ast },\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(14)</span></div>where <em>f</em><sub>\u03c3</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03c3<sub>*</sub>/\u03c3<sub>g</sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a02 is the ratio of the velocity dispersion of the stars to that of the gas (Korchagin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). We define the gas fraction, <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>, such that <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ15\" content-id=\"equ15\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nf_{\\rm gas} = \\frac{M_{\\rm gas}}{M_{\\rm gas} + M_{\\ast }} \\approx \\frac{\\Sigma _{\\rm g}}{\\Sigma _{\\rm g} + \\Sigma _{\\ast }},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(15)</span></div>if we measure the gas and stars over the same area. Combining equations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ13\"></span><a href=\"#equ13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">13</a>)\u2013(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ15\"></span><a href=\"#equ15\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">15</a>), we have <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ16\" content-id=\"equ16\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\Sigma _{\\rm SFR} = A \\left( \\Sigma _0 \\left( \\frac{f_{\\rm gas}\\left( 1 + f_{\\sigma } \\right)}{f_{\\rm gas}\\left( 1 + f_{\\sigma } \\right) + 2\\left( 1 - f_{\\rm gas}\\right)}\\right)\\right)^{n}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(16)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thus, from equations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ12\"></span><a href=\"#equ12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">12</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ16\"></span><a href=\"#equ16\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">16</a>), we find that the cut-off mass, <em>M</em><sub>0</sub>, and the clump SFR surface density, \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub>, depend on \u03a3<sub>0</sub>, \u03ba and <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>. In order to understand how <em>M</em><sub>0</sub> and \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub> evolve with redshift, we therefore need to understand the evolution of \u03a3<sub>0</sub>, \u03ba and <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We can estimate \u03a3<sub>0</sub> and <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> from our data using the \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub> derived from H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 and applying the Kennicutt\u2013Schmidt law from equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ13\"></span><a href=\"#equ13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">13</a>) to derive \u03a3<sub>gas</sub>. To estimate \u03a3<sub>*</sub>, we use the total <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> from the SED fitting and apportion the stellar mass according to the fractional flux in each pixel of the reddest available <em>HST</em> image. We then combine the \u03a3<sub>gas</sub> and \u03a3<sub>*</sub> maps to create a map of \u03a3<sub>0</sub>. There are many uncertainties in estimating of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> from H\u03b1, specifically, the assumption of a constant Kennicutt\u2013Schmidt law and in the reliability of the SED-derived stellar masses; none the less, we note that our estimate for the Cosmic Eye of <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a010<sup>9</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> is very close to the CO-derived value of <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(9.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.6)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In our sample, we find a mean \u3008<em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0\u3009\u00a0= 0.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1, consistent with the evolution observed in CO (e.g. Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Livermore et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We estimate \u03ba by taking the velocity at the half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> along the dynamical axis from the disc fitting, where there is no inclination correction for the radius. This measurement is highly uncertain as the measurement of <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> is affected by the clumpy morphologies and the irregular source-plane PSF, and the measurement of the velocity includes uncertainty in the inclination. We find a median \u03ba\u00a0\u223c\u00a090\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, consistent with the predictions of Dutton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using these models for the evolution of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>, \u03a3<sub>0</sub> and \u03ba, we should be able to predict how the star formation surface density of clumps, \u03a3<sub>clump</sub> and the cut-off mass, <em>M</em><sub>0</sub>, evolve. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, we present an updated version of the figure in Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>, fig. 9) including the IFU data. We find that the evolution in the cut-off of the clump mass function and in the surface brightness of clumps is consistent with the model predictions given by equations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ12\"></span><a href=\"#equ12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">12</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ16\"></span><a href=\"#equ16\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">16</a>), given evolution in the galaxy mass and dynamics from theoretical predictions, and empirical gas fraction evolution. This indicates that galaxies at high redshift appear clumpy because their gas-rich discs fragment on larger scales, leading to star-forming clumps that dominate the morphology of the galaxy. Thus, despite the different appearance of high-redshift clumpy galaxies to local spirals, we find that they do not require a different \u2018mode\u2019 of star formation; the clumps can arise naturally as a consequence of the larger gas reservoirs.</p>                        <a id=\"17053714\" scrollto-destination=\"17053714\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=TbXIAzJu-k0rsZbpFR4CFbJXK92ipHryizG2cvIniDFidDp3yFA3iwAfsK~gcLkt55pACFnFrBUUNdCniadJTB~rrY~KDMsqQWo4iJE8nJZ1iIQANXX11FjJvJVtlNpkDZv0hrUsD1W1fyGRMsgGYsDX7Cr1dBWPoFfHnUcsufMne-bC~jBjljp07W6x1nR2fUpCCPY6ftUGVvJe-VvKjDph9SKGYwSu~gZzqmq2TYrQPS0r6kHRTPbn-uVJlKkXnRlpexD8mKXbWbtYPGtV4~eGfYm3R2YiOV-jQgW09KbxvUTX8TkBAOuN5g1xNtQRVbI9gI0tyxoGJigqBmiC6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Evolution of clump surface brightness \u03a3SFR and the cut-off mass M0 derived from the clumps luminosity functions. The dashed line shows a predicted track based on equations (12) and (16) assuming evolution in mass and epicyclic frequency from the simulations of Dutton et\u00a0al. (2011) and gas fraction evolution of fgas\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0z)2 (Geach et\u00a0al. 2011), with f\u03c3\u00a0=\u00a02. The shaded regions indicate the predicted locations of clumps in each redshift bin, for a range of gas fractions fgas\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0z)(2.0\u00b10.5). The data are consistent with the model, demonstrating that the \u2018clumpy\u2019 morphologies of high-z galaxies are driven by evolution in their gas fractions and dynamics.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig11.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053714/stv686fig11.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig11.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053714\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=tHDPnABaBnE7lBQl0gs8ffdwNWSTteLVtaEzJEwWxg3Y~MwJyxFw3PaPGeSni3JD5PVZ5FjTXPSWYtnVtr2RUa14E9cO7~Q~6~mArBdT5Y-0~i75SHP7Pn7DoQ9vSDeMYDvpVlWPrkhuoM8tL4PfiZAJdEO6M545Su~6bIvBNHSNNguWtiWHciLnVJ0vP2rma~BU1hNcoK~m4wnk27G~uejuqTaVBtRANCWvf-bunsDQHEgbsXNHMopJsRlvjwUsDTX~sMOT9iqCBf4wkFxoje3EWqXKpXmPJLxWD1vyV5eXP6QhvU8Td5tcgHMGGsefbhHKlHn0TjDQFEAFu4axaw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053714&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig11.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evolution of clump surface brightness \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub> and the cut-off mass <em>M</em><sub>0</sub> derived from the clumps luminosity functions. The dashed line shows a predicted track based on equations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ12\"></span><a href=\"#equ12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">12</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ16\"></span><a href=\"#equ16\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">16</a>) assuming evolution in mass and epicyclic frequency from the simulations of Dutton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and gas fraction evolution of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>)<sup>2</sup> (Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), with <em>f</em><sub>\u03c3</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02. The shaded regions indicate the predicted locations of clumps in each redshift bin, for a range of gas fractions <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>)<sup>(2.0\u00b10.5)</sup>. The data are consistent with the model, demonstrating that the \u2018clumpy\u2019 morphologies of high-<em>z</em> galaxies are driven by evolution in their gas fractions and dynamics.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=TbXIAzJu-k0rsZbpFR4CFbJXK92ipHryizG2cvIniDFidDp3yFA3iwAfsK~gcLkt55pACFnFrBUUNdCniadJTB~rrY~KDMsqQWo4iJE8nJZ1iIQANXX11FjJvJVtlNpkDZv0hrUsD1W1fyGRMsgGYsDX7Cr1dBWPoFfHnUcsufMne-bC~jBjljp07W6x1nR2fUpCCPY6ftUGVvJe-VvKjDph9SKGYwSu~gZzqmq2TYrQPS0r6kHRTPbn-uVJlKkXnRlpexD8mKXbWbtYPGtV4~eGfYm3R2YiOV-jQgW09KbxvUTX8TkBAOuN5g1xNtQRVbI9gI0tyxoGJigqBmiC6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Evolution of clump surface brightness \u03a3SFR and the cut-off mass M0 derived from the clumps luminosity functions. The dashed line shows a predicted track based on equations (12) and (16) assuming evolution in mass and epicyclic frequency from the simulations of Dutton et\u00a0al. (2011) and gas fraction evolution of fgas\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0z)2 (Geach et\u00a0al. 2011), with f\u03c3\u00a0=\u00a02. The shaded regions indicate the predicted locations of clumps in each redshift bin, for a range of gas fractions fgas\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0z)(2.0\u00b10.5). The data are consistent with the model, demonstrating that the \u2018clumpy\u2019 morphologies of high-z galaxies are driven by evolution in their gas fractions and dynamics.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig11.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053714/stv686fig11.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig11.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053714\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=tHDPnABaBnE7lBQl0gs8ffdwNWSTteLVtaEzJEwWxg3Y~MwJyxFw3PaPGeSni3JD5PVZ5FjTXPSWYtnVtr2RUa14E9cO7~Q~6~mArBdT5Y-0~i75SHP7Pn7DoQ9vSDeMYDvpVlWPrkhuoM8tL4PfiZAJdEO6M545Su~6bIvBNHSNNguWtiWHciLnVJ0vP2rma~BU1hNcoK~m4wnk27G~uejuqTaVBtRANCWvf-bunsDQHEgbsXNHMopJsRlvjwUsDTX~sMOT9iqCBf4wkFxoje3EWqXKpXmPJLxWD1vyV5eXP6QhvU8Td5tcgHMGGsefbhHKlHn0TjDQFEAFu4axaw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053714&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig11.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evolution of clump surface brightness \u03a3<sub>SFR</sub> and the cut-off mass <em>M</em><sub>0</sub> derived from the clumps luminosity functions. The dashed line shows a predicted track based on equations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ12\"></span><a href=\"#equ12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">12</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ16\"></span><a href=\"#equ16\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">16</a>) assuming evolution in mass and epicyclic frequency from the simulations of Dutton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and gas fraction evolution of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>)<sup>2</sup> (Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), with <em>f</em><sub>\u03c3</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02. The shaded regions indicate the predicted locations of clumps in each redshift bin, for a range of gas fractions <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>)<sup>(2.0\u00b10.5)</sup>. The data are consistent with the model, demonstrating that the \u2018clumpy\u2019 morphologies of high-<em>z</em> galaxies are driven by evolution in their gas fractions and dynamics.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17053715 id=\"17053715\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented integral field spectroscopy around the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission lines of 12 gravitationally lensed galaxies at 1\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a04, obtained with VLT/SINFONI, Keck/OSIRIS and Gemini/NIFS. We combine these data with five galaxies from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) and investigate the dynamics and star formation properties of 17 high-redshift galaxies. The galaxies all benefit from magnification due to gravitational lensing, increasing the flux by factors of 1.4\u201390\u00a0times and providing sub-kpc spatial resolution, though we stress that uncertainties are introduced by the anisotropic magnification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our combined sample has stellar masses <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a06\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u20136\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> and dust extinctions of <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.4\u20131.1. The intrinsic SFRs derived from the H\u03b1 (or H\u03b2) emission, after correcting for lensing and dust extinction, are SFR\u223c0.8\u201340\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The use of gravitational lensing therefore allows us to probe the representative star-forming population at this epoch, with lower <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> and SFRs than other high-<em>z</em> surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit rotating disc models to the sample to derive inclinations and dynamical axes, from which we extract rotation curves and velocity dispersion profiles. All of the galaxies in the combined sample have velocity gradients, and 14 out of 17 are well fit by an arctan function indicative of rotation. Of the sample, 59\u2009per\u2009cent have velocity profiles indicative of rotation, centrally peaked velocity dispersion profiles and sufficiently high <em>v</em>/\u03c3 to be classed as possible rotating discs. Of the remainder, 29\u2009per\u2009cent have disturbed profiles that may be indicative of merging or interacting systems. The remaining two galaxies are undetermined as we do not see a turnover in their rotation curves. The merger fraction is in good agreement with other high-<em>z</em> kinematic surveys (e.g. F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Epinat et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), while, like Newman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), we find that higher spatial resolution causes a higher fraction of the remainder to be classed as rotating discs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As gravitational lensing allows us to probe intrinsically smaller galaxies, we extend relationships observed between galaxy size, velocity and <em>v</em>/\u03c3 in unlensed samples to smaller sizes. Our results support previous work finding that larger galaxies generally have a higher contribution to their kinematic support from ordered rotation compared to random motions, but we find a large degree of scatter in these smaller galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that the sample is consistent with the local stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation with no coherent evidence for redshift evolution, in common with the work of Miller et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We further demonstrate that the rotation in our sample, which comprises systematically smaller sizes than unlensed studies, could be dominated by baryons (see also Miller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We extend the work of Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) and Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) by detecting 50 star-forming clumps in our sample and study their luminosities, sizes and velocity dispersions. In common with previous work, we find that the surface brightness evolves with redshift, but we extend this evolution to <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03. The average star formation density in the brightest clumps evolves with redshift as log\u2009(\u03a3<sub>clump</sub>/M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>)\u00a0=\u00a0(3.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5)log\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>) \u2212 (1.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2). However, we find that the clumps have similar velocity dispersions to unlensed high-<em>z</em> samples while being smaller and less luminous; thus, they introduce a much larger degree of scatter into the <em>L</em>\u2013\u03c3 and \u03c3\u2013<em>r</em> relations observed in other studies. This could be an indication that these clumps are not virialized, and that their velocity dispersions may have additional contributions from star formation feedback or gravitational instability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We construct luminosity functions of the clumps, and find that they can be fit by a Schechter function in which the cut-off evolves to higher luminosities at higher redshifts. We find that the cut-off evolves as log\u2009(<em>L</em><sub>0</sub>/erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)\u00a0=\u00a0(2.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)log\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>)\u00a0+\u00a0(41.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2). This supports the picture in which \u2018clumpy\u2019 galaxies arise at high-<em>z</em> because gas-rich, turbulent discs fragment on larger scales, resulting in star-forming regions large enough to dominate the morphology of the galaxy. The gas content of high-redshift galaxies remains relatively unexplored due to the small number of observations of molecular gas in normal high-redshift star-forming galaxies. It is to be hoped that the redshift evolution of gas fractions and the universality of the Kennicutt\u2013Schmidt law can be tested as the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) in full science operations opens up the more normal star-forming population.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based in part on observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory under programme IDs 083.B-0108, 085.B-0848 and 087.B-0875. Also based in part on observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory under programme ID GN-2010B-Q-61. The Gemini Observatory is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF on behalf of the Gemini partnership: the National Science Foundation (United States), the National Research Council (Canada), CONICYT (Chile), the Australian Research Council (Australia), Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o (Brazil) and Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnolog\u00eda e Innovaci\u00f3n Productiva (Argentina). RCL acknowledges a studentship from STFC for most of the duration of this project, and funding from the University of Texas at Austin for the latter part. JR is supported by the Marie Curie Career Integration Grant 294074. RGB and IS are supported by STFC and IS further acknowledges a Leverhulme Senior Fellowship. AMS is funded by an STFC Advanced Fellowship, and HE gratefully acknowledges financial support from STScI grants GO-09722, GO-10491, GO-10875 and GO-12166.</p>                    <h2 data-legacy-id=\"bib9\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib9\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib9\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"volume\">115</div>\u00a0pg.\u00a0<div class=\"fpage\">763</div>\u00a0<!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/pasp.2003.115.issue-809\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1086%2Fpasp.2003.115.issue-809\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1086%2Fpasp.2003.115.issue-809\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib10\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib10\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib10\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib10\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib10\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib10\"><div class=\"citation element-citation\"><span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Conselice</div> <div class=\"given-names\">C. J.</div></div>,\u00a0 <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bundy</div> <div class=\"given-names\">K.</div></div>,\u00a0 <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ellis</div> <div class=\"given-names\">R. id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert \">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry at-widget-entry-SCL\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\"
