The top-left image in each panel shows an HST image of the arc constructed from archival ACS and/or WFC3 data, in colour where there are multiple bands in the archive. The filters used are given in the lower-left corner of the image. The critical line at the target galaxy's redshift is overlaid in red. Where the IFU field of view cannot cover the entire arc, it is shown as a dashed white box. The lower-left image shows the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line flux, aligned to the same astrometry as the HST image for context. The right four images in each panel show the source-plane reconstructions: from top left to bottom right, they show the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 intensity maps, velocity fields, line-of-sight velocity dispersion and velocity field residuals after subtracting the best-fitting disc model. The star-forming clumps are contoured over the intensity maps. Contours overlaid on the velocity field show the best-fitting disc model after smoothing by the effective source-plane PSF, shown by a magenta ellipse. As surface brightness is conserved by lensing, the image and source-plane intensity maps are displayed in terms of surface brightness, with the same scaling.\"}\r\n    </script>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:site_name\" content=\"OUP Academic\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:type\" content=\"article\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:title\" content=\"Resolved spectroscopy of gravitationally lensed galaxies: global dynamics and star-forming clumps on \u223c100&#160;pc scales at 1&#160;&amp;lt;&#160;z&#160;&amp;lt;&#160;4\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:description\" content=\"Abstract. The filters used are given in the lower-left corner of the image. The critical line at the target galaxy&#39;s redshift is overlaid in red. Where the IFU field of view cannot cover the entire arc, it is shown as a dashed white box. The star-forming clumps are contoured over the intensity maps. Contours overlaid on the velocity field show the best-fitting disc model after smoothing by the effective source-plane PSF, shown by a magenta ellipse.                if (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            var $adblockDiv = $(this).find('.js-adblock');\r\n                            var $adText = $(this).find('.js-adblock-advertisement-text');\r\n                            if ($adblockDiv && $adblockDiv.is(':visible') && $adblockDiv.find('*').length > 1) {\r\n                                $adText.removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                            else {\r\n                    <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main accessible-content-title at-articleTitle\">\r\n                        Resolved spectroscopy of gravitationally lensed galaxies: global dynamics and star-forming clumps on \u223c100\u00a0pc scales at 1\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a04\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                    </h1>\r\n\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors at-ArticleAuthors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                            <div class=\"meta-authors--limited\">\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-name js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                        <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">R. C. Livermore</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    R. C. Livermore\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" data-open=\"cor1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-default\"><sup>\u2605</sup></a></span>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><span class=\"label\">1</span>Institute for Computational Cosmology, Durham University, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK</div><div class=\"aff\"><span class=\"label\">2</span>Department of Astronomy, The University of Texas at Austin, 2515 Speedway Stop C1400, Austin, TX 78712, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-author-correspondence\">\r\n        <span class=\"label\">\u2605</span>E-mail: <a href=\"mailto:r.c.livermore@astro.as.utexas.edu\" target=\"_blank\">r.c.livermore@astro.as.utexas.edu</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=R.+C.+Livermore\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Livermore R.   $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-cite js-item-cite\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\r\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button at-CiteButton\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal>\r\n    <i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i>\r\n    <span>Cite</span>\r\n</a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal js-citation-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>R. C. Livermore, T. A. Jones, J. Richard, R. G. Bower, A. M. Swinbank, T.-T. Yuan, A. C. Edge, R. S. Ellis, L. J. Kewley, Ian Smail, K. E. K. Coppin, H. Ebeling,  Resolved spectroscopy of gravitationally lensed galaxies: global dynamics and star-forming clumps on \u223c100\u00a0pc scales at 1\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a04, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 450, Issue 2, 21 June 2015, Pages 1812\u20131835, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stv686\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stv686</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form action=\"/Citation/Download\" method=\"get\" id=\"citationModal\">\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"resourceId\" value=\"982124\" />\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\r\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=Resolved%20spectroscopy%20of%20gravitationally%20lensed%20galaxies%3A%20global%20dynamics%20and%20star-forming%20clumps%20on%20%E2%88%BC100%C2%A0pc%20scales%20at%201%C2%A0%26amp%3Blt%3B%C2%A0%26lt%3Bem%26gt%3Bz%26lt%3B%2Fem%26gt%3B%C2%A0%26amp%3Blt%3B%C2%A04&amp;publicationDate=2015-04-29&amp;volumeNum=450&amp;issueNum=2&amp;author=Livermore%2C%20R.%20C.%3B%20Jones%2C%20T.%20A.&amp;startPage=1812&amp;endPage=1835&amp;contentId=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstv686&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\" class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution js-nav-dropdown\">\r\n                            University class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17053591 id=\"17053591\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present adaptive optics-assisted integral field spectroscopy around the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 lines of 12 gravitationally lensed galaxies obtained with VLT/SINFONI, Keck/OSIRIS and Gemini/NIFS. We combine these data with previous observations and investigate the dynamics and star formation properties of 17 lensed galaxies at 1\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a04. Thanks to gravitational magnification of 1.4\u201390\u00a0times by foreground clusters, effective spatial resolutions of 40\u2013700\u00a0pc are achieved. The magnification also allows us to probe lower star formation rates (SFRs) and stellar masses than unlensed samples; our target galaxies feature dust-corrected SFRs derived from H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission of \u223c0.8\u201340\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and stellar masses <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a04\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u20136\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>. All of the galaxies show velocity gradients, with 59\u2009per\u2009cent consistent with being rotating discs and a likely merger fraction of 29\u2009per\u2009cent, with the remaining 12\u2009per\u2009cent classed as \u2018undetermined\u2019. We extract 50 star-forming clumps with sizes in the range 60\u00a0pc\u20131\u00a0kpc from the H\u03b1 (or H\u03b2) maps, and find that their surface brightnesses, \u03a3<sub>clump</sub> and their characteristic luminosities, <em>L</em><sub>0</sub>, evolve to higher luminosities with redshift. We show that this evolution can be described by fragmentation on larger scales in gas-rich discs, and is likely to be driven by evolving gas fractions.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: kinematics and dynamics&quot;\">galaxies: kinematics and dynamics</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: star formation&quot;\">galaxies: star formation</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17053593 id=\"17053593\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Advances in observational facilities and instrumentation over recent decades have led to a rapid accumulation of data on the statistical properties of galaxy populations and their evolution with cosmic time. Most notably, it is established that the cosmic star formation rate (SFR) density peaked around <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01 and has since declined by an order of magnitude (Lilly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Madau et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Hopkins &amp; Beacom <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Sobral et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and that more than half of the present-day stellar mass had been formed by <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01 (e.g. Dickinson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Patel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The challenge now is to interpret these statistical trends and to uncover the underlying physical processes at work. How did these early galaxies form their stars, and what conditions have changed over time to result in the observed evolution of their integrated properties?</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Star formation is a complex process driven by the interplay of competing effects: self-gravitating gas is supported against collapse by turbulent motion and by feedback in the form of radiation pressure from hot, young stars and active galactic nuclei. An understanding of the evolution of star-forming galaxies therefore requires an understanding of the evolving dynamics of galaxies at different epochs. A population of rapidly star-forming galaxies at high redshift implies the presence of large gas reservoirs. Since the dynamics of gas and stars are intrinsically different \u2013 stars comprise a collisionless system, while gas is collisional and can dissipate energy \u2013 it is to be expected that high-redshift galaxies will have systematically different dynamics than those found locally.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The advent of near-infrared integral field units (IFUs) on 8\u201310m class telescopes presented the opportunity to study two-dimensional velocity fields. At <em>z</em>\u00a0\u2273\u00a01, the optical nebular emission lines such as H\u03b1 are redshifted into the near-infrared, with [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] visible out to <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a05, providing bright tracers of the underlying dynamics in ionized gas across a large redshift range.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">IFU studies of the dynamics of high-<em>z</em> galaxies quickly revealed that a significant fraction, around 1/3, are rotating systems in place as early as <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02, but that they show higher velocity dispersions than local galaxies. They also found that \u223c1/3 are \u2018dispersion-dominated\u2019 non-rotators, with the remaining \u223c1/3 comprising merging systems (F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Epinat et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, see Glazebrook <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a> for a comprehensive review).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A common feature in H\u03b1 maps of high-redshift galaxies from IFU studies is the irregular, clumpy morphology of the H\u03b1 emission. These have also been observed in high-resolution imaging (Cowie, Hu &amp; Songaila <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Elmegreen, Elmegreen &amp; Sheets <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Elmegreen &amp; Elmegreen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Elmegreen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and termed \u2018clump cluster\u2019 or \u2018chain\u2019 galaxies. The prevailing view is that these clumps form from internal gravitational instabilities in gas-rich discs (Elmegreen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Bournaud et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Their ubiquity in galaxies with ordered rotation supports this view, as clumps forming through major mergers would be expected to disrupt the dynamics (e.g. Bournaud &amp; Elmegreen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Bournaud et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Dekel, Sari &amp; Ceverino <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The study of dynamics and star formation morphologies of high-redshift galaxies is hampered by spatial resolution. Even with adaptive optics, the current generation of telescopes can achieve resolution of \u223c1\u20131.5\u00a0kpc at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02. This limits the number of spatial resolution elements, as not only are galaxies intrinsically smaller at high redshift, but cosmological surface brightness dimming \u2009\u221d\u2009(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>z</em>)<sup>4</sup> limits observations to the bright central regions. Beam-smearing also affects measurements of velocity dispersion, which includes contributions from the underlying velocity gradient as well as local turbulent motion, and can smooth out rotation curves to give slowly rotating galaxies the appearance of being dispersion-dominated (e.g. Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053601 id=\"17053601\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1-1>1.1 Gravitational magnification</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Enhanced spatial resolution can be achieved with current facilities by targeting galaxies that benefit from strong gravitational lensing by massive foreground clusters. As well as stretching the galaxy images and thus increasing the spatial resolution of observations, lensing conserves surface brightness, which means that the total flux is effectively magnified. This enables us to study galaxies whose intrinsic luminosities lie below the detection limits of current surveys, opening up more \u2018normal\u2019 galaxies, where unlensed surveys have by necessity focused on the more extreme star-forming population.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">By taking advantage of magnification due to strong gravitational lensing, high-resolution dynamics in high-redshift galaxies have been observed, revealing a high fraction to have ordered rotation (Nesvadba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>). Star-forming clumps are also visible in these galaxies, and due to the high spatial resolution can be observed on \u223c100\u00a0pc scales, enabling direct comparisons with the H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in which stars form in the local Universe (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>). Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) used H\u03b1 narrow-band imaging to study clumps in star-forming galaxies at 0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02 and showed that both their surface brightnesses and luminosity functions evolve with redshift, with the higher redshift galaxies having more massive, brighter clumps with higher surface brightnesses. The high-<em>z</em> clumps can be explained by the same formation process as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in local galaxies: a marginally stable disc fragments on scales related to its Jeans mass. At high redshift, higher gas fractions cause collapse on larger scales, leading to clumps large enough to dominate the galaxy's morphology. This factor alone, however, overpredicts the luminosities of high-<em>z</em> clumps. Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) therefore suggested a contribution from the epicyclic frequency, which is higher at high redshift and acts to stabilize the disc, causing collapse on smaller scales.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This model effectively explains the evolution in observed clump properties, but relies on the dynamics of the galaxies, which were derived from disc scaling relations and not measured in the data. In this paper, therefore, we use integral field spectroscopy of lensed galaxies to examine the evolution of galaxy dynamics in combination with the properties of star-forming clumps. The paper is organized as follows: we present the sample and describe the data reduction and derivation of galaxy properties in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, we analyse the results and discuss first the dynamics and then the star-forming clumps, and we discuss the formation and evolution of star-forming clumps in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>. Finally, we summarize our conclusions in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. Throughout, we adopt a \u039bCDM cosmology with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u2009km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=17053605 id=\"17053605\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS AND DATA REDUCTION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053606 id=\"17053606\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Integral field spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the galaxies in our sample, which were selected from clusters with existing mass models, and to have spectroscopically confirmed redshifts that place their H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission in windows of atmospheric transmission in the near-infrared and away from OH emission lines. In order to ensure detection in \u223c5\u00a0h, we targeted galaxies with integrated emission line fluxes of &gt;10<sup>\u221216</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, known either from prior spectroscopy or from spectroscopic pre-imaging (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"17053608\" scrollto-destination=\"17053608\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" Eye\u00a0</td><td>21:35:12.73\u00a0</td><td>\u221201:01:43.0\u00a0</td><td>3.07\u00a0</td><td>OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td><em>Kn</em>1\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>21.6\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> (a) To identify the arcs, we use the cluster names and the arc ID from the published lens model or the system number where we observe multiple images of the same galaxy, except for the Cosmic Eye which is also known as LBG J213512.73-010143. MACS clusters are truncations of MACSJ0744.8+3927, MACSJ1149.5+2223, MACSJ0451.9+0006, MACSJ0712.3+5931 and MACSJ2135.2'0102 (Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Mann &amp; Ebeling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). (b) Positions and redshifts are given for the target lensed arcs.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/17053608\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap ><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>19.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2895-arc1.1+1.2\u00a0</td><td>01:18:11.15\u00a0</td><td>\u221226:58:03.9\u00a0</td><td>3.40\u00a0</td><td>SINFONI\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em>\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>19.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2895-arc2.2\u00a0</td><td>01:18:10.45\u00a0</td><td>\u221226:58:14.2\u00a0</td><td>3.72\u00a0</td><td>SINFONI\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em>\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>26.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cl0024-arc1.1\u00a0</td><td>00:26:34.42\u00a0</td><td>+17:09:55.4\u00a0</td><td>1.68\u00a0</td><td>OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td><em>Hn</em>5\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b1\u00a0</td><td>16.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cl0949-arc1\u00a0</td><td>09:52:49.78\u00a0</td><td>+51:52:43.7\u00a0</td><td>2.39\u00a0</td><td>OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td><em>Hn</em>4\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b1\u00a0</td><td>19.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS0712-system1\u00a0</td><td>07:12:17.51\u00a0</td><td>+59:32:16.3\u00a0</td><td>2.65\u00a0</td><td>OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td><em>Kc</em>5\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>16.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACSJ0744-arc1\u00a0</td><td>07:44:47.82\u00a0</td><td>+39:27:25.7\u00a0</td><td>2.21\u00a0</td><td>OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td><em>Kn</em>2\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b1\u00a0</td><td>14.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cosmic Eye\u00a0</td><td>21:35:12.73\u00a0</td><td>\u221201:01:43.0\u00a0</td><td>3.07\u00a0</td><td>OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td><em>Kn</em>1\u00a0</td><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>21.6\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> (a) To identify the arcs, we use the cluster names and the arc ID from the published lens model or the system number where we observe multiple images of the same galaxy, except for the Cosmic Eye which is also known as LBG J213512.73-010143. MACS clusters are truncations of MACSJ0744.8+3927, MACSJ1149.5+2223, MACSJ0451.9+0006, MACSJ0712.3+5931 and MACSJ2135.2'0102 (Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Mann &amp; Ebeling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). (b) Positions and redshifts are given for the target lensed arcs.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/17053608\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The new sample comprises 12 galaxies, of which 10 were observed with the SINFONI IFU on the ESO/VLT (Eisenhauer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) between 2009 April 30 and 2012 July 16. The SINFONI targets were selected to be close to sufficiently bright stars for the use of NGS+AO, resulting in a median FWHM = 0.2\u00a0arcsec. As the lensed arcs are extended, usually over several arcseconds, we used the 8\u00a0arcsec\u00d78\u00a0arcsec field of view with a spaxel size of 0.25\u00a0arcsec. Due to the elongated shape typical of lensed arcs, the targets were kept in one half of the IFU and nodded across in an ABBA sequence. We observed each target for six ABBA sequences in the <em>H</em>- or <em>K</em>-band filter according to the redshifted position of the target emission line (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). We also observe [N<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] in the H\u03b1 targets and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] in the H\u03b2 targets; the properties of these lines will be discussed in a future paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data were reduced using the <span class=\"small-caps\">esorex</span> package, which performs flat-fielding and wavelength calibration and reforms the image into a data cube with two spatial and one spectral dimension. It also carries out sky subtraction by subtracting each B frame from its closest A frame, which with our observing strategy results in cubes that contain two images of the target, one positive and one negative. Standard stars were observed on the same nights and in the same filters as the science exposures, and were reduced in the same way. We used the standard stars to individually flux-calibrate each cube before combining them.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To combine the cubes, we first cut them in half to separate the two images of the target, and subtracted the negative image from the positive one. We then aligned the cubes by collapsing them into continuum images. As the targets all lie behind cluster lenses, they commonly have elliptical cluster members close to their line of sight. Where possible, a foreground elliptical galaxy was intentionally positioned within the SINFONI field of view to allow careful alignment between cubes. Where this was not possible (in the case of the two arcs lensed by the cluster Abell 2895), we aligned the cubes by centring on a bright feature within the lensed galaxy. Once aligned, the cubes were median-combined with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">imcombine</span> with the <span class=\"monospace\">crreject</span> algorithm for cosmic ray rejection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the 10 targets observed with SINFONI, we observed a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.28 galaxy lensed by the cluster MACS J0744+3927 with Gemini/Near-Infrared Integral Field Spectrometer (NIFS; McGregor et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). The lensed target is denoted MACS0744-system3. As the target is too long to fit in the 3\u00a0arcsec\u00d73\u00a0arcsec field of view (see the first panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), we observed in an ABC sequence, where two halves of the arc were positioned diagonally across the field in the A and C frames, and the B frame was a blank field used for sky subtraction. The A and C frames were chosen to overlap at the foreground elliptical in the middle of the arc to enable precise alignment of the A and C frames. We observed for eight ABC sequences with the <em>H</em>-band filter. Data reduction was carried out using the \u2018<span class=\"small-caps\">gemini</span>\u2019 package in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> of both the science frames and standard stars observed on the same nights and with the same setup as the science observations. Each cube was then individually flux-calibrated and combined as for the SINFONI observations described above.</p>                        <a id=\"17053613\" scrollto-destination=\"17053613\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1a\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig1a.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=RU4AKL3a2xqoohGPV3vjA75ArzDyqg2HLjgF2FfE~NPxegZbFylajw380V-RShks5UsORj43JMM5OMcJ26QrN-b0Sr-uc8cCJ301Ln3xxRw4oU483r9UIkqrxGlU9si8pBig8F~s-VMGnVx~KJ97I87aRt-Z6y5JvYzXNwSW~KVTK5m5fOXEF0oA7Og9ARgjU3VW9cREaEkIc0VWtp7IZkfaQ6S0Plemb2yJpoQoIjCMLGNOfKuDyaOXR7kv0EBC0VpIYwHNJkX3kFpysgVu89gptaub4uhKcQ~AaCA-VErsUgJgq3H6r2lrKiNO8tVyrvg0Ze4dkqZnuPBs1go6bw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image plane colour images (where available) and reconstructed source-plane maps of the target galaxies. The top-left image in each panel shows an HST image of the arc constructed from archival ACS and/or WFC3 data, in colour where there are multiple bands in the archive. The filters used are given in the lower-left corner of the image. The critical line at the target galaxy's redshift is overlaid in red. Where the IFU field of view cannot cover the entire arc, it is shown as a dashed white box. The lower-left image shows the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line flux, aligned to the same astrometry as the HST image for context. The right four images in each panel show the source-plane reconstructions: from top left to bottom right, they show the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 intensity maps, velocity fields, line-of-sight velocity dispersion and velocity field residuals after subtracting the best-fitting disc model. The star-forming clumps are contoured over the intensity maps. Contours overlaid on the velocity field show the best-fitting disc model after smoothing by the effective source-plane PSF, shown by a magenta ellipse. As surface brightness is conserved by lensing, the image and source-plane intensity maps are displayed in terms of surface brightness, with the same scaling.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig1a.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053613/stv686fig1a.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig1a.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053613\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig1a.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=2CSwD2FZn-6OX2jDp-mN5F7EsDYWVjkJzpQhlpyvrjfS7BWbvp2pdRpnUSUeIoCOlAUBP5P712Kwp-RulufAecxNpPaiTAjN3xW9Ot76~7-RJnujJ19fC03QpsLNbp2muiKraD7grlumZ91YFqRfjbWuU6hskjXhttywbxr8Kfyn7AKa-zaV-dlgf-Bk~14eUqPkQdyixtRor3ogtC0b8hZh1uH~ZwXaM9~uge0izl2mf1MKWNHnZzG3ETrnsimKkbMcojgJORd87~PxeeKcblqJ3Fcy~xRSgUkp1Uwznf95RR-Fbe-YBk9~j5VvLNgHZMU2qOOvrBad6s--StY7Vg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053613&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig1a.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image plane colour images (where available) and reconstructed source-plane maps of the target galaxies. The top-left image in each panel shows an <em>HST</em> image of the arc constructed from archival <em>ACS</em> and/or <em>WFC3</em> data, in colour where there are multiple bands in the archive. The filters used are given in the lower-left corner of the image. The critical line at the target galaxy's redshift is overlaid in red. Where the IFU field of view cannot cover the entire arc, it is shown as a dashed white box. The lower-left image shows the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line flux, aligned to the same astrometry as the <em>HST</em> image for context. The right four images in each panel show the source-plane reconstructions: from top left to bottom right, they show the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 intensity maps, velocity fields, line-of-sight velocity dispersion and velocity field residuals after subtracting the best-fitting disc model. The star-forming clumps are contoured over the intensity maps. Contours overlaid on the velocity field show the best-fitting disc model after smoothing by the effective source-plane PSF, shown by a magenta ellipse. As surface brightness is conserved by lensing, the image and source-plane intensity maps are displayed in terms of surface brightness, with the same scaling.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1a\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig1a.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=RU4AKL3a2xqoohGPV3vjA75ArzDyqg2HLjgF2FfE~NPxegZbFylajw380V-RShks5UsORj43JMM5OMcJ26QrN-b0Sr-uc8cCJ301Ln3xxRw4oU483r9UIkqrxGlU9si8pBig8F~s-VMGnVx~KJ97I87aRt-Z6y5JvYzXNwSW~KVTK5m5fOXEF0oA7Og9ARgjU3VW9cREaEkIc0VWtp7IZkfaQ6S0Plemb2yJpoQoIjCMLGNOfKuDyaOXR7kv0EBC0VpIYwHNJkX3kFpysgVu89gptaub4uhKcQ~AaCA-VErsUgJgq3H6r2lrKiNO8tVyrvg0Ze4dkqZnuPBs1go6bw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image plane colour images (where available) and reconstructed source-plane maps of the target galaxies. The top-left image in each panel shows an HST image of the arc constructed from archival ACS and/or WFC3 data, in colour where there are multiple bands in the archive. The filters used are given in the lower-left corner of the image. The critical line at the target galaxy's redshift is overlaid in red. Where the IFU field of view cannot cover the entire arc, it is shown as a dashed white box. The lower-left image shows the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line flux, aligned to the same astrometry as the HST image for context. The top-left image in each panel shows an <em>HST</em> image of the arc constructed from archival <em>ACS</em> and/or <em>WFC3</em> data, in colour where there are multiple bands in the archive. The filters used are given in the lower-left corner of the image. The critical line at the target galaxy's redshift is overlaid in red. Where the IFU field of view cannot cover the entire arc, it is shown as a dashed white box. The lower-left image shows the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line flux, aligned to the same astrometry as the <em>HST</em> image for context. The right four images in each panel show the source-plane reconstructions: from top left to bottom right, they show the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 intensity maps, velocity fields, line-of-sight velocity dispersion and velocity field residuals after subtracting the best-fitting disc model. The star-forming clumps are contoured over the intensity maps. As surface brightness is conserved by lensing, the image and source-plane intensity maps are displayed in terms of surface brightness, with the same scaling.</p></div></div>                        <a class=\"chapter-para\">\u2013\u2002<em>continued</em></p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1g\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig1g.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=o3zgxDXWWNiuTNseRzXoab--hIxNZGAWbB0VFMaBStqHWMcg2nDXNjAdfcFVuVQMC1y7h57xjE6~VXmTRzyPq12uTfTS0TjIzsFsh2omyPovTniLyv68isADasab4Pva6qiJ-rsqUhTn6l307g-MfVff2caw0NgrUmi4CNmLZBsmW25ipFYQ7IC5yx-vDLJCR1spOmHyGNUb~VzgymJ0eIG-8PS03sTok-wPudd2yeB0dLAE22XM3-7JEV4wE9JvQhbnRb3Oxn~3PtNNKYo1trB4-gdA~W1Cch8vDniZ4P8x7Afh7LMTljzwuC5gBzkSUMrscISmnU5bqnRImoxK3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2013\u2002continued\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig1g.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053619/stv686fig1g.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig1g.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig1g.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=U0lAxzvOdSggbfiq5pz-A3KuLOAX8K~EzDQnFiaPASReMgnUm0i1uGU2J869q5D1Z7-daZkokf3lsZzrXzOZ7Ka2WyoT3mME~FPuTfzopBU0qCMYCOQpmpSlt6Vm3~aPnwco3CF~IirnoZocTO9x5ca1u05VsSpPuMaGcLZQuAuvlyYOMqiiLLGGorKPeQwlb0tPb6dQHmTWffOlSvEE-SPdyCr43hR1yXSHeSFKV454bG-00FXYfQmnygf4WhPvB1C5K1gWVPptX7n2XuV5JW7o~FuP9Ptd~Yj8~LVsw6X4DZSIvupGEejxGTzK4bqBv-yk7Q2qlbkrMWHEosf6CA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053619&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig1g.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2013\u2002<em>continued</em></p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">One further target, the spiral galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.49 lensed by the cluster MACS J1149.5+2223 (MACS1149-arcA1.1), was observed with Keck/OSIRIS. The observations and data reduction are described by Yuan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), who use the data to show that the galaxy's metallicity gradient is strongly negative.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper, we also make use of the sample of six lensed galaxies observed with Keck/OSIRIS from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>). They presented the resolved kinematics of these galaxies, which we adopt in the first half of this paper for comparison with our new data. They also demonstrated that individual star-forming clumps could be extracted from the data and discussed their properties in relation to local H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions, deriving luminosity densities up to 100\u00a0times higher than local star-forming regions. So that they can be combined with the new data in a self-consistent manner, we undertake a new analysis of the clump properties in this sample in the latter half of this paper, but our results are entirely consistent with those presented by Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>). One of these galaxies \u2013 MACS0451-system7, observed in H\u03b1 by Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) \u2013 is also included in the SINFONI sample, where we observed it in H\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]. The combined sample of lensed arcs thus comprises 17 galaxies at 1.28\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.72.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17053622 id=\"17053622\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-1>2.1.1 Unlensed samples</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For comparison purposes, we refer throughout this paper to three other IFU surveys of high-redshift galaxies, which are not lensed. For ease of reference, we summarize the main properties of these surveys as follows: </p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">SINS+AO: this is a subset of the Spectroscopic Imaging survey in the Near-infrared with SINFONI (SINS; F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>) sample which has been observed with adaptive optics (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The sample comprises 38 star-forming galaxies selected via their UV or optical emission, and has <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.2. These galaxies sample the massive end of the star-forming \u2018main sequence,\u2019 with stellar masses of 10<sup>9.2</sup>\u201310<sup>11.5</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> and SFRs of 13\u2013850\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The spatial resolution achieved with SINFONI+AO is \u223c0.2\u00a0arcsec, equivalent to 1.7\u00a0kpc.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">SHiZELS: a sample of nine galaxies at 0.84\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.23 drawn from the High-<em>Z</em> Emission Line Survey (HiZELS), observed with SINFONI+AO (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). The spatial resolution of 01\u00a0arcsec equates to 0.8\u00a0kpc at the sample's median redshift, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.47. The sample covers a similar range of stellar masses (<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a010<sup>9</sup>\u201310<sup>11</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>) to the SINS sample, but with lower SFRs of 7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">WiggleZ: this sample comprises 13 <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.3 galaxies selected from the WiggleZ Dark Energy Survey and observed with Keck/OSIRIS+LGSAO (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The spatial resolution of these observations is \u223c01\u00a0arcsec, or 0.8\u00a0kpc. The range of stellar masses covered is similar to the other two surveys at 10<sup>9.8</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a010<sup>11.7</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and SFRs are in the range 30\u2013200\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></li></ul>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053625 id=\"17053625\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 <em>HST</em> imaging and lens modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) colour images (where available) of the target galaxies are shown in the top-left panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. In order to determine the intrinsic properties of the target galaxies, it is necessary to account for the effects of lensing. To do this, we use the best-fitting cluster mass models, the details of which are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Where the cluster's critical line at the redshift of the lensed arc crosses the field, it is overlaid in red. The critical line denotes regions of theoretically infinite magnification, and arcs which cross this line are multiply imaged within the IFU field of view. To reconstruct the source-plane images of the galaxies, we use <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to ray-trace each pixel to its source-plane origin. After using a central pixel to obtain the position of the galaxy in the source plane, we construct a regular grid in the source plane, ray-trace each pixel to the image plane and obtain the spectrum in that position by interpolating between pixels in the IFU data cube. In the cases of A1835-arc7.1 and A2895-arc2.2, the high-magnification gradient in the vicinity of the critical line causes this method to omit data from the image plane. For these galaxies, we therefore carry out the process in reverse by ray-tracing each pixel from the IFU data cube to the source plane. This results in an irregular grid in the source plane, which is gridded into square pixels using a Delauney tessellation. Once the source-plane cubes have been constructed, we apply conservation of surface brightness to each pixel to obtain the intrinsic source-plane flux. The magnification factor \u03bc for the galaxy given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> is then the ratio of image- to source-plane flux measured from the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission lines.</p>                        <a id=\"17053627\" scrollto-destination=\"17053627\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lens properties of the sample.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03bc<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03bc<sub>lin</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Resolution (pc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Lens model reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(a)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(b)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(c)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MACS0744-system3\u00a0</td><td>63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a022\u00a0</td><td>21\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>134\u00a0\u00b1\u00a047\u00a0</td><td>Jones et\u00a0al. (b) \u03bc<sub>lin</sub> gives the linear magnification factors in the direction of greatest magnification and perpendicular to that axis. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS0712-system1\u00a0</td><td>28\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a011\u00a0</td><td>Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACSJ0744-arc1\u00a0</td><td>16\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>9\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a015\u00a0</td><td>Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cosmic Eye\u00a0</td><td>28\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>96\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> (a) \u03bc is the total magnification of the source, derived from the ratio of the emission line flux in the image plane to that in the source plane. (b) \u03bc<sub>lin</sub> gives the linear magnification factors in the direction of greatest magnification and perpendicular to that axis. (c) Resolution is given in the direction of greatest magnification.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/17053627\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">With both methods, the source-plane pixel scale is chosen so that each pixel in the IFU data cube is represented in the source plane, and we impose a lower limit of 0.001\u00a0arcsec to ensure manageable file sizes. The pixel scale is therefore dictated by the direction or region of highest magnification. Gravitational lensing usually acts preferentially in one direction, and galaxies lying close to the critical line will experience strong magnification gradients. Hence, the source-plane cubes are oversampled both in the direction of lower magnification and in regions of the galaxy that lie furthest from the critical line. To estimate the actual resolution achieved, we apply the same reconstruction as described above to the standard star observations and measure the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) in the image and source plane. The result is an ellipse, shown in magenta in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. We remind the reader that while lensing brings a major improvement in the spatial resolution that can be achieved, this gain is not without its problems. For example, in many systems the magnification is much higher in one direction than the other, leading to a distorted image of the galaxy. While we find that reconstruction of the original image is not problematic for the lenses considered here, this limitation should be born in mind when assessing the overall morphology of the source. The effective point spread functions (PSFs) shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> illustrate the extent of anisotropy in each system, and we give values for the magnification in each direction in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to estimate the errors on the magnification factors for each galaxy, we use the family of 100 best-fitting lens models. We use <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> to reconstruct the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 intensity maps for each galaxy for each one of the possible lens models, and then measure the ratio of image- to source-plane flux in each. The 1\u03c3 deviation in the derived magnifications are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> as the error on the total magnification. As we measure the magnification for the purpose of this paper from the H\u03b1 (or H\u03b2) line intensity (effectively a weighted mean), the largest errors are found where there is a large magnification gradient across the arc without strong constraints on the mass distribution of the primary lensing source. The largest fractional error, 35\u2009per\u2009cent, is found in MACS0744-system3, due to the strong magnification gradient across the image arising from lensing by the foreground cluster galaxy positioned along the line of sight to the arc. The smallest error, 5\u2009per\u2009cent, is found in A1835-arc7.1, which also has a strong magnification gradient, but in this case the two images straddling the critical line provide good constraints on the precise position of the line. We note that changing the lens model tends to result in the galaxy image being stretched differently, so that the effective resolution described above would change, but the underlying morphology cannot be materially altered. Crucially for the discussion in the latter half of this paper, new features such as clumps cannot be created during the lensing reconstruction.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053630 id=\"17053630\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Dynamical maps</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">With both the image- and source-plane cubes, we fit the intensity, velocity and velocity dispersion of the emission lines in each pixel using a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization technique. In each pixel, we simultaneously fit the H\u03b1 and [N<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb6583 or H\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb\u03bb4959,5007 lines. To reduce the number of parameters in the fit, we require all lines to be of the same velocity and velocity dispersion, and we impose a ratio of [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb\u20095007/\u03bb\u20094959\u00a0=\u00a03 (Storey &amp; Zeippen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The fit is accepted if it results in a \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u00a0&gt;\u00a025 compared to a straight-line fit, equivalent to a signal to noise of S/N\u00a0&gt;\u00a05. If no fit is obtained, we adaptively bin up to 3 \u00d7 3\u00a0pixels in the image plane, or the equivalent area of 3 \u00d7 3 PSF areas in the source plane. We deconvolve the velocity dispersion for spectral resolution by subtracting in quadrature the median width of sky lines measured from blank exposures taken with the standard stars. The high spatial resolution of the source-plane cube means that most of the contribution to the velocity dispersion of the velocity gradient across the galaxy is removed. To remove the remainder, we subtract in quadrature the velocity gradient across each pixel, measured over the PSF. For each parameter, we also estimate the errors in each pixel. Taking the best fit to the emission lines, we vary each parameter in turn, while allowing the others to find their new minima, until we obtain a \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u00a0\u2265\u00a01.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show the resulting maps in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. In the bottom left of each panel is the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line intensity from the image-plane IFU data, mapped to the same astrometry as the <em>HST</em> image. The source-plane reconstructions are in the right-four images of each panel, showing the H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 emission line intensity, the velocity and velocity dispersion maps and the velocity residuals after subtracting the best-fitting disc models (contoured over the velocity map and described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1</a>). We note that as the velocity and velocity dispersion are fixed between multiple emission lines, their values are dominated by the line with the highest S/N. In the case of the H\u03b2/[O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] observations, the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb\u20095007 line is far brighter than the H\u03b2 line; in some cases, we thus obtain velocity and velocity dispersion values in pixels where no H\u03b2 is measured. We note that the method above is the same as that used by Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), so the properties derived from the two samples are self-consistent.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053633 id=\"17053633\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Disc modelling</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To each of the velocity fields, we follow Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) and attempt to fit a rotating disc model and hence infer the true disc rotation speed and inclination. The model is described by six parameters: the disc centre <em>x</em> and <em>y</em>, the asymptotic rotational velocity <em>v</em><sub>asym</sub>, the turnover radius <em>r</em><sub>t</sub>, the position angle \u03d5 and inclination \u03b8. The values of these parameters are constrained so that <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> are within the range of the data, and <em>r</em><sub>t</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0kpc. Rotation is described by an arctan function (Courteau <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) of the form <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nv(r) = \\left( \\frac{2}{\\pi }\\right) v_{\\rm {asym}}\\arctan \\left( \\frac{r}{r_{\\rm t}} \\right).\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fit is carried out with an iterative procedure whereby 10\u2009000 random sets of parameters are generated, and the resulting 2D velocity models are smoothed by the effective source-plane PSF of the galaxy in order to account for the effect of asymmetric magnification. The \u03c7<sup>2</sup> is then calculated for each one. The parameter space is contracted by discarding up to 10\u2009per\u2009cent of the worst-fitting models in each iteration. This process is repeated up to 100\u00a0times, and the fit is deemed to have converged once all models in a generation have \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01. The smoothed best-fitting disc models are contoured on the observed velocity fields in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and the velocity residuals after subtracting the best-fitting disc model are shown in the bottom-right image of each panel. The dynamical properties of the sample are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"17053636\" scrollto-destination=\"17053636\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dynamical properties of the sample.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Inclination<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>v</em>/<em>r</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>v</em>/\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Disc/Merger/<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span c2.1\u00a0</td><td>81\u00a0</td><td>38\u00a0</td><td>64\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1689-arc1.2\u00a0</td><td>80\u00a0</td><td>234\u00a0</td><td>78\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>53\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>1.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2895-arc1.1+1.2\u00a0</td><td>85\u00a0</td><td>260\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>62\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>Undetermined\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2895-arc2.2\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>276\u00a0</td><td>200\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>530\u00a0\u00b1\u00a030\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cl0024-arc1.1\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td><td>122\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08\u00a0</td><td>63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06\u00a0</td><td>15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>2.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cl0949-arc1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>68\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>16\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Merger\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS0712-system1\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td><td>351\u00a0</td><td>33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>75\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>0.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACSJ0744-arc1\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td><td>124\u00a0</td><td>118\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>110\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td><td>210\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>2.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cosmic Eye\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0</td><td>113\u00a0</td><td>51\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>Disc\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Inclination<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>v</em>/<em>r</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>v</em>/\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Disc/Merger/<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> Inclination and PA are derived from the best-fitting disc models. <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> is the velocity at 2.2<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, where <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> is the half-light radius. Velocity dispersion, \u03c3, is the luminosity-weighted mean local value, after deconvolving for local velocity gradient. The velocity gradient <em>v</em>/<em>r</em> is measured at <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>. Targets below the line are from Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) with values reported in their table 2, except for <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub>, <em>v</em>/<em>r</em> and <em>v</em>/\u03c3, which we measure for consistency with the new data. No values for \u03b8, PA or <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> are given for Cl0949-arc1 as this galaxy cannot be fit by a disc model.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;
