The grey crosses indicate the average error on the SINS points. The dashed line is the fit to the SINS data from Newman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The intrinsically smaller lensed galaxies extend the non-lensed samples to smaller sizes, but the correlation is weaker.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=M-esqedA8sxdmfQ5teZK5UkcR9ypC7OamCCYxal6ijGrlUxthmj5Rpows2VisyAH2E9~ZgSyH8KKeYRKNcXjDJWDMucXyfPneqlgI9uYrnmZ--XLHa~pSXTrQttXUmDoVq~I-X52WtMnorm9XE872Z2c3bCqvwSmySSTyh1aaYgfCzbEGMXY1Rk~eKg-XP2iwmo6bUKmlRCJ2GgpXAx1gaRKud4dup2ysS5q1-c-eV1DAfkKWfSN5M-KaRvKYABWVIVlKgmAFxIVZivxthtwGIM0ku8gkvBESepWcyQHUKq762S4uLenBUr2CQEDORWcZbcEm5KubMCeDKy3Pwa8lA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: relation between rotational velocity and half-light radius. Right: vrot/\u03c3 against half-light radius. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift on the same scale in both plots, with filled symbols representing those galaxies identified as discs, and unfilled symbols mergers or undetermined systems. Comparison samples are included from the high-z lensed sources of Jones et\u00a0al. (2010a), and the unlensed high-z IFU surveys SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012a), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. 2013). The grey crosses indicate the average error on the SINS points. The dashed line is the fit to the SINS data from Newman et\u00a0al. (2013). The intrinsically smaller lensed galaxies extend the non-lensed samples to smaller sizes, but the correlation is weaker.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig4.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053663/stv686fig4.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig4.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053663\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=kgQVaC~vnvxdN0N3Wl1qT-dmpDZHhmK~upUUvrzv-uCN~eU9RXs6ddCaoW3rzFOYjbvmYBdpYENh6LOvvXWdlVYt1Vt0MO957Ozx~sxPxyC4aCPi6SU2jiaFjY5F3d3z3ejaNfCUknor7sJhkFU9PhoajK-1DeFS7u3wa1b10lq1nVIHvqpUOF733S-Z8GEk8M7KOHFYXYbLffaepaFnx-M~fjMvIy6X2PXILmFrznEnHO6aT~4kUmQIKKbJNKYhdqqYlo80MG01vhuSfSYOlomeyJqYsCTAVkuuSQTY5k9xtCAtZgz0CVGkdoDW1UbauyTWz4o9HA2tQTbsvP29GA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053663&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig4.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: relation between rotational velocity and half-light radius. Right: <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 against half-light radius. The lensed arcs are colour-coded by redshift on the same scale in both plots, with filled symbols representing those galaxies identified as discs, and unfilled symbols mergers or undetermined systems. Comparison samples are included from the high-<em>z</em> lensed sources of Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), and the unlensed high-<em>z</em> IFU surveys SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>), WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The grey crosses indicate the average error on the SINS points. The dashed line is the fit to the SINS data from Newman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The intrinsically smaller lensed galaxies extend the non-lensed samples to smaller sizes, but the correlation is weaker.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 to <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> gives similar results; we find higher scatter at low <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, but there remains a weak positive correlation (Spearman rank correlation coefficient \u03c1\u00a0=\u00a00.52) in the combined lensed and unlensed data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In both cases, there is no systematic difference in this scatter between the rotation-dominated galaxies and those identified as non-disc systems. The lack of correlation seen in the lensed sample with respect to the unlensed galaxies therefore implies a fundamental difference in the kinematic properties. As discussed below, this is likely due to the systematically smaller sizes and lower masses of the lensed galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, we plot stellar mass, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, as a function of <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3, finding that our combined sample continues the relation observed in the non-lensed SINS+AO sample to lower stellar masses, although with significant scatter. However, there is little correlation with the unlensed SHiZELS and WiggleZ data. This could be because they are observed with similar resolution to the SINS data, but have systematically smaller sizes, and thus a larger contribution from beam smearing. The best fit to the combined lensed and SINS+AO unlensed data is log\u2009(<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>)\u00a0=\u00a01.2log\u2009(<em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3)\u00a0+\u00a09.7.</p>                        <a id=\"17053667\" scrollto-destination=\"17053667\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=wFc9Eyf7dktTFaG6J8XBqHpLkERxonRxrMPh5HNmTQtN-lZB9h5B00HMhlxD6F7qOfzYGfq9CV-boH6PMUsuFTSjzqTfTZr3MVt7Dkpr6222j2cF52hwolSr-zrvexPFPKzi5q7b6~BHnliqXmptiMVrEY5DgxXdAxBiqdOfQZ4ErMARShKQqqEtUZsKMpUWHOXEBOJtH4v1Nv5iZavXkDCr7hWXiTFsIjpSejVvVkfcPyZm65UI6zWrNsmh6MB05BAyeZgr8YGiz4hCdjjvih8PoZ5FXA8N1UYyBNwE17Le8JLsqbDGxCOSRBU7UW2BwxhyqoW9WHpSapOtLVf9Fw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relation between stellar mass, M*, and vrot/\u03c3. The rotational velocity vrot is corrected for inclination, and \u03c3 is the luminosity-weighted mean velocity dispersion, corrected for beam smearing. The SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. 2013), SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012a) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2011) are also shown for comparison with higher stellar mass systems at high redshift. The grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS data, and the dashed line is the best fit to the SINS\u00a0+\u00a0lensed samples. We find that lensed galaxies with high vrot/\u03c3 tend to have high M*, indicating that galaxies become more dynamically \u2018settled\u2019 as they build up more mass.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig5.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053667/stv686fig5.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig5.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053667\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=CIh3hePfx~VGURckv9vRD3r~P3LDy~gFeY2-yDcygGhEMEdl7-MTzJdD5eSApr5hPDdaYnk4LY7R5ymZ-YRtE7cOnjZ73fYV3WoOey9pkGgD8j0YujMtmxAAulUXmn5ApHnGKqXn-KHyR-4oiL7v6AH5D1X1HKNHEK8g6mqRXtr8IZ-IC8Xustqx4W3JJwYqP-ArMVHBhXb-5J6JRtRMTjnvZg-~FKIKms49l-9UWPAc9mkZ2wAeMfvZIZpudYJF4MQ0M8ylDLEP6iItwa2lR3-W4AT2xDCq1G6iDbjUu3jYXgMzqDzXqifzXeZ~zRuuhLpmXGAOYZrOVsLtKsDAiw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053667&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig5.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relation between stellar mass, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, and <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3. The rotational velocity <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> is corrected for inclination, and \u03c3 is the luminosity-weighted mean velocity dispersion, corrected for beam smearing. The SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) are also shown for comparison with higher stellar mass systems at high redshift. The grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS data, and the dashed line is the best fit to the SINS\u00a0+\u00a0lensed samples. We find that lensed galaxies with high <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 tend to have high <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, indicating that galaxies become more dynamically \u2018settled\u2019 as they build up more mass.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=wFc9Eyf7dktTFaG6J8XBqHpLkERxonRxrMPh5HNmTQtN-lZB9h5B00HMhlxD6F7qOfzYGfq9CV-boH6PMUsuFTSjzqTfTZr3MVt7Dkpr6222j2cF52hwolSr-zrvexPFPKzi5q7b6~BHnliqXmptiMVrEY5DgxXdAxBiqdOfQZ4ErMARShKQqqEtUZsKMpUWHOXEBOJtH4v1Nv5iZavXkDCr7hWXiTFsIjpSejVvVkfcPyZm65UI6zWrNsmh6MB05BAyeZgr8YGiz4hCdjjvih8PoZ5FXA8N1UYyBNwE17Le8JLsqbDGxCOSRBU7UW2BwxhyqoW9WHpSapOtLVf9Fw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relation between stellar mass, M*, and vrot/\u03c3. The rotational velocity vrot is corrected for inclination, and \u03c3 is the luminosity-weighted mean velocity dispersion, corrected for beam smearing. The SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. 2013), SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2012a) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. 2011) are also shown for comparison with higher stellar mass systems at high redshift. The grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS data, and the dashed line is the best fit to the SINS\u00a0+\u00a0lensed samples. We find that lensed galaxies with high vrot/\u03c3 tend to have high M*, indicating that galaxies become more dynamically \u2018settled\u2019 as they build up more mass.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig5.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053667/stv686fig5.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig5.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053667\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=CIh3hePfx~VGURckv9vRD3r~P3LDy~gFeY2-yDcygGhEMEdl7-MTzJdD5eSApr5hPDdaYnk4LY7R5ymZ-YRtE7cOnjZ73fYV3WoOey9pkGgD8j0YujMtmxAAulUXmn5ApHnGKqXn-KHyR-4oiL7v6AH5D1X1HKNHEK8g6mqRXtr8IZ-IC8Xustqx4W3JJwYqP-ArMVHBhXb-5J6JRtRMTjnvZg-~FKIKms49l-9UWPAc9mkZ2wAeMfvZIZpudYJF4MQ0M8ylDLEP6iItwa2lR3-W4AT2xDCq1G6iDbjUu3jYXgMzqDzXqifzXeZ~zRuuhLpmXGAOYZrOVsLtKsDAiw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053667&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig5.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relation between stellar mass, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, and <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3. The rotational velocity <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> is corrected for inclination, and \u03c3 is the luminosity-weighted mean velocity dispersion, corrected for beam smearing. The SINS AO sample (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), SHiZELS (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) and WiggleZ (Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) are also shown for comparison with higher stellar mass systems at high redshift. The grey cross indicates the typical error on the SINS data, and the dashed line is the best fit to the SINS\u00a0+\u00a0lensed samples. We find that lensed galaxies with high <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 tend to have high <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, indicating that galaxies become more dynamically \u2018settled\u2019 as they build up more mass.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">If we interpret <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>/\u03c3 as a measure of the \u2018order\u2019 in a system, where <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> measures the ordered rotation and \u03c3 constitutes turbulent or disordered motion, this relationship suggests that galaxies become more ordered as they build up higher stellar masses, a process described as \u2018kinematic settling\u2019 (Kassin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Therefore, in the lensed sample, which probes systematically smaller intrinsic sizes and lower masses than the unlensed surveys, we see less contribution from ordered rotation as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, and hence do not see the correlations exhibited by the larger, more massive unlensed galaxies.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=17053669 id=\"17053669\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 The stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Tully\u2013Fisher relation relates the stellar content of galaxies to their rotational velocity (Tully &amp; Fisher <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1977</a>). In a model in which gas cools from a dark matter halo into a rotating disc, maintaining the angular momentum of its parent halo, the Tully\u2013Fisher relation is interpreted as a relationship between the baryonic content of galaxies and the angular momentum of their dark matter haloes. As such, it is a key parameter that models of galaxy evolution must reproduce.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Attempts to place observational constraints on the redshift evolution of the Tully\u2013Fisher relation have had inconclusive results. Observations of the <em>B</em>-band Tully\u2013Fisher relation at high redshift demonstrate modest evolution, but are affected by recent star formation and so evolution of the <em>B</em>-band mass-to-light ratio (Vogt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). We therefore concentrate on the more physical stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation, but this too has produced mixed results, with no coherent evidence of evolution out to <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 (Conselice et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Cresci et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Flores et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kassin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Puech et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Miller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Vergani et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). Miller, Sullivan &amp; Ellis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) found that bulge-less galaxies at high-<em>z</em> are the ones that show the greatest offset from the local relation, which they interpret as evidence that these galaxies have yet to \u2018mature\u2019 on to the Tully\u2013Fisher relation, perhaps related to higher gas fractions in their discs. Similarly, Gnerucci et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) investigated the stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a03 and found marginal evolution but with a large amount of scatter, concluding that the relation may not be in place at this epoch.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To compare different galaxies, it is important to measure <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> in a consistent manner. Measurements of the rotation curve are naturally sensitive to the surface brightness of the galaxy and the depth of the observations. Courteau (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) compared various methods of measuring <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> and found that <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> (the velocity interpolated from the model rotation curve at a radius <em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u2009<em>h</em>, where <em>h</em> is the disc scalelength) performed best in terms of minimal internal scatter and residuals from the Tully\u2013Fisher relation and provided the best match to radio (21\u00a0cm) results. In high-redshift galaxies with clumpy and disturbed morphologies, the light does not follow a pure exponential disc profile, so we cannot strictly use this definition with our data. We therefore adopt the half-light radius, <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, as a proxy for the disc scalelength, and measure <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> from the model rotation curve fits, corrected for inclination, at <em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u2009<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>. For consistency across the sample, we re-analyse the velocity fields of the Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample in order to extract <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> from these galaxies. Our derived <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> values are slightly lower than the inclination-corrected <em>v</em><sub>max</sub> that they derive by an average of 20\u2009per\u2009cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We plot the stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. We find that most of our lensed arcs are consistent with the Tully\u2013Fisher relation observed in other samples, but with considerable scatter. Three galaxies lie well above the local relation, with low <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> for their stellar masses. Of these, two are from the Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample; these are Cl0949-arc1 and the Cosmic Eye. The former was identified as a merger by Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), though the latter appears to be a rotationally supported disc (see Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The remaining galaxy lying above the local relation A1413-arc2.1a, which appears to be interacting with A1413-arc2.1b.</p>                        <a id=\"17053674\" scrollto-destination=\"17053674\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=3xz8UP-lEUrksAFACRYdMMkBgSVbQ5ZjPCMoHFNJzINfLrSZiAEdy5Uxp3UimZL~Gn9Tdl0bYvas4MxIkJaA~iISZPln4bWfPlMcc6cV2KqOeozmX3fehXa12vVCT4Ih59iLAFKtc-yW76but6FMdErjkn8g4ka4dcfqMLeWexhGiYaRvhMD5WsenTcO92W5Bqvv5o2q3bLH4LmPJaYZUbHfFrBXo7A99bReORmplnkbjEFTHmfRZmTsdQjS8GNfph3~5QB~hH2R2fkyOt~iGRptukiO4VxnxMtqg2-8C4ijWWR~AFz-Q-cO97K~9DhwjjRnX21tsg00zAEEP5wAMA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation. The stellar mass, M*, is estimated from SED fitting to the available HST and Spitzer imaging. The rotation velocity v2.2 is measured from the model rotation curves interpolated at a radius of r\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u2009r1/2, where r1/2 is the half-light radius. The z\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from Pizagno et\u00a0al. (2005), and the solid line is the best fit to these points. High-redshift comparison data are from the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 lensed arcs of Jones et\u00a0al. (2010a), the z\u00a0=\u00a01 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2006), the DEIMOS z\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.6 and z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.3 samples of Miller et\u00a0al. (2011, 2012), the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02\u20133.5 SINS and AMAZE surveys (Cresci et\u00a0al. 2009; Gnerucci et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SHiZELS 0.84\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.3 sample of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2012a). The dotted line indicates the predicted evolution of the Tully\u2013Fisher relation at z\u00a0=\u00a02 from simulations (Crain et\u00a0al. 2009). We colour-code our lensed arcs by redshift, and show rotating disc-like systems with filled symbols, and mergers and dispersion-dominated systems with open symbols. We find that most of our sample is largely consistent with the z\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, but with significant scatter discussed further in the text.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig6.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053674/stv686fig6.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig6.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053674\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=igw1rkH~BhGMrTxkO2m3Y-gC0NVLWe5NgQw-oLaPGQ8igMtB9FFGR1Y6Tha0ZMLbT0v~DnBkWTWg2vCAmaubIrtsfuYQB3dx0-NwZN1WxnkCLLx9G6BcwcDahq6esjk0ec0Ta9ZCg29T~Kn9VtiMzRNPL4E2avByxktdbHVJM3k6px8pEqMvvg407pZuyA5UySlPu-Xzlx4UDBsbwaLYpsafq28F2varCw2A7s9nqBZW8navaj2jTPgK-gKCIMjbrElmHr~6LLMvS0J2hH-C-g8hHnP3UufY5LYd820gHIIRyp2asdelYczWNu~9QDFi3Bdg-z36~ACRAqpOmtQ3Tg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053674&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig6.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation. The stellar mass, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, is estimated from SED fitting to the available <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> imaging. The rotation velocity <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> is measured from the model rotation curves interpolated at a radius of <em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u2009<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, where <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> is the half-light radius. The <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from Pizagno et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), and the solid line is the best fit to these points. High-redshift comparison data are from the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 lensed arcs of Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), the DEIMOS <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.6 and <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.3 samples of Miller et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02\u20133.5 SINS and AMAZE surveys (Cresci et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Gnerucci et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SHiZELS 0.84\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.3 sample of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). The dotted line indicates the predicted evolution of the Tully\u2013Fisher relation at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 from simulations (Crain et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). We colour-code our lensed arcs by redshift, and show rotating disc-like systems with filled symbols, and mergers and dispersion-dominated systems with open symbols. We find that most of our sample is largely consistent with the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, but with significant scatter discussed further in the text.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=3xz8UP-lEUrksAFACRYdMMkBgSVbQ5ZjPCMoHFNJzINfLrSZiAEdy5Uxp3UimZL~Gn9Tdl0bYvas4MxIkJaA~iISZPln4bWfPlMcc6cV2KqOeozmX3fehXa12vVCT4Ih59iLAFKtc-yW76but6FMdErjkn8g4ka4dcfqMLeWexhGiYaRvhMD5WsenTcO92W5Bqvv5o2q3bLH4LmPJaYZUbHfFrBXo7A99bReORmplnkbjEFTHmfRZmTsdQjS8GNfph3~5QB~hH2R2fkyOt~iGRptukiO4VxnxMtqg2-8C4ijWWR~AFz-Q-cO97K~9DhwjjRnX21tsg00zAEEP5wAMA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation. The stellar mass, M*, is estimated from SED fitting to the available HST and Spitzer imaging. The rotation velocity v2.2 is measured from the model rotation curves interpolated at a radius of r\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u2009r1/2, where r1/2 is the half-light radius. The z\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from Pizagno et\u00a0al. (2005), and the solid line is the best fit to these points. High-redshift comparison data are from the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 lensed arcs of Jones et\u00a0al. (2010a), the z\u00a0=\u00a01 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2006), the DEIMOS z\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.6 and z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.3 samples of Miller et\u00a0al. (2011, 2012), the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02\u20133.5 SINS and AMAZE surveys (Cresci et\u00a0al. 2009; Gnerucci et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SHiZELS 0.84\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.3 sample of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2012a). The dotted line indicates the predicted evolution of the Tully\u2013Fisher relation at z\u00a0=\u00a02 from simulations (Crain et\u00a0al. 2009). We colour-code our lensed arcs by redshift, and show rotating disc-like systems with filled symbols, and mergers and dispersion-dominated systems with open symbols. We find that most of our sample is largely consistent with the z\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, but with significant scatter discussed further in the text.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig6.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053674/stv686fig6.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig6.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053674\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=igw1rkH~BhGMrTxkO2m3Y-gC0NVLWe5NgQw-oLaPGQ8igMtB9FFGR1Y6Tha0ZMLbT0v~DnBkWTWg2vCAmaubIrtsfuYQB3dx0-NwZN1WxnkCLLx9G6BcwcDahq6esjk0ec0Ta9ZCg29T~Kn9VtiMzRNPL4E2avByxktdbHVJM3k6px8pEqMvvg407pZuyA5UySlPu-Xzlx4UDBsbwaLYpsafq28F2varCw2A7s9nqBZW8navaj2jTPgK-gKCIMjbrElmHr~6LLMvS0J2hH-C-g8hHnP3UufY5LYd820gHIIRyp2asdelYczWNu~9QDFi3Bdg-z36~ACRAqpOmtQ3Tg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053674&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig6.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stellar mass Tully\u2013Fisher relation. The stellar mass, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, is estimated from SED fitting to the available <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> imaging. The rotation velocity <em>v</em><sub>2.2</sub> is measured from the model rotation curves interpolated at a radius of <em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.2\u2009<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>, where <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> is the half-light radius. The <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 data are from Pizagno et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), and the solid line is the best fit to these points. High-redshift comparison data are from the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 lensed arcs of Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 lensed arcs of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), the DEIMOS <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.6 and <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.3 samples of Miller et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02\u20133.5 SINS and AMAZE surveys (Cresci et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Gnerucci et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SHiZELS 0.84\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.3 sample of Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). The dotted line indicates the predicted evolution of the Tully\u2013Fisher relation at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 from simulations (Crain et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). We colour-code our lensed arcs by redshift, and show rotating disc-like systems with filled symbols, and mergers and dispersion-dominated systems with open symbols. We find that most of our sample is largely consistent with the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, but with significant scatter discussed further in the text.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Simulations predict that the zero-point of the Tully\u2013Fisher relation should decrease at high redshift (e.g. Crain et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; McCarthy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, indicated by a dotted line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Semi-analytic models in which the disc dynamics are driven by the dark matter halo make a similar prediction (Dutton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). However, Benson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) predicts a modest <em>positive</em> increase in the zero-point at high redshift. As Miller et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) point out, the primary difference is that the Benson model has a larger contribution from baryons. High-redshift galaxies are intrinsically smaller than their present-day counterparts \u2013 especially in the lensed sample that probes the smaller, fainter population \u2013 and so we might expect the dynamics within 2.2<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> to be dominated by baryons (see also Miller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In the simplest case of orbital circular motion, we should see <em>v</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>GM</em>/<em>r</em> for total enclosed mass <em>M</em>. To test whether this is a better description of our data, we divide the <em>y</em>-axis of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> by 2.2<em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> and show the result in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. The scatter is significantly reduced in comparison to Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, and the line <em>v</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>GM</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>r</em> provides a good fit to the lensed and SHiZELS data, although the same three lensed galaxies remain far outside this relation. The varying gas fractions in the galaxies will contribute significantly to the scatter in this relation. The other comparison samples have a systematically higher velocities at a given <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>r</em>, perhaps suggesting that their dynamics do have contributions from the dark matter halo, whereas the dynamics of the lensed galaxies within the central few kpc are dominated by baryons.</p>                        <a id=\"17053676\" scrollto-destination=\"17053676\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=KkM7uTGGpaebGI6rLIGOJ9IO8xQhF7l-pv6bU3OA7ID0G2iWzZItAuH7dXdaoOEvJtgbawt9VR4fqlCqoU2xS6AfyG5u1bcU1fxz6bym56gf8QEqEORJjg3kgsMxRFwW3XXuBJKrIAxEtlBfP4Y5dJmMjdZbecCHciooV0oQuNuXQSAfXjupOu476A~wgXZB-7xFt~gDUoEpnCgC~U7KpRU4btJ~XZUjaFNee0mqTc60PYWzUekl3yCtkLDyeXUdZpnqjrAEjjsA3KzcTyJ6x5fyG~dU2SWPJtCglnXn0Sut4N0w2qp7iixZuXMmf3liI~RQ~WJYwrlNCDHMXjlu9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The ratio between stellar mass and galaxy radius as a function of rotational velocity, where radius is defined as 2.2 disc scalelengths and the velocity is corrected for inclination. Comparison data are from the same sources as in Fig.\u00a06. The dashed line indicates v2\u00a0=\u00a0GM*/r. The lensed galaxies and some data from the other samples, in particular from SHiZELS, lie along this line, indicating that their dynamics are dominated by baryons in the discs. There is no apparent systematic difference between disc-like (filled symbols) and mergers/dispersion-dominated systems (open symbols) in the lensed samples. Offsets from this line are likely related to the gas fractions of the galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig7.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053676/stv686fig7.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig7.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053676\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=e2WC9jDCmp4RGxJcElnnMAdkJT5Nonxr06ljHeb6cx1nyln~ygabJ5ddFVU8BwIlZdUfCcu7km7SkIeHDI8Px4IRTd03IkJO1e3hJQTUR6OFAsAC~-sMWxjkP3r8JcM7YRfHpGTCmIM45syA-JmmHCtCfUNMGfLmaa6-U23ps~39cLqNNEHMm-c8C2GvWKbfi7DJT5X3wY0lelJaXcQOg-vZK6xZmkz4zWWcLqOmwQ~VrepiCJ5w~ieWfnKfOMkPAl7~V3NGFforWSXKv2BQrO0zJdRaRLmfpJq7YJLZlmyDGSlcVoiAYSfgrxngIpDGiQ47NiPv8IgIvr2sa5oKjw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053676&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig7.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ratio between stellar mass and galaxy radius as a function of rotational velocity, where radius is defined as 2.2 disc scalelengths and the velocity is corrected for inclination. Comparison data are from the same sources as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The dashed line indicates <em>v</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>GM</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>r</em>. The lensed galaxies and some data from the other samples, in particular from SHiZELS, lie along this line, indicating that their dynamics are dominated by baryons in the discs. There is no apparent systematic difference between disc-like (filled symbols) and mergers/dispersion-dominated systems (open symbols) in the lensed samples. Offsets from this line are likely related to the gas fractions of the galaxies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/m_stv686fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&amp;Signature=KkM7uTGGpaebGI6rLIGOJ9IO8xQhF7l-pv6bU3OA7ID0G2iWzZItAuH7dXdaoOEvJtgbawt9VR4fqlCqoU2xS6AfyG5u1bcU1fxz6bym56gf8QEqEORJjg3kgsMxRFwW3XXuBJKrIAxEtlBfP4Y5dJmMjdZbecCHciooV0oQuNuXQSAfXjupOu476A~wgXZB-7xFt~gDUoEpnCgC~U7KpRU4btJ~XZUjaFNee0mqTc60PYWzUekl3yCtkLDyeXUdZpnqjrAEjjsA3KzcTyJ6x5fyG~dU2SWPJtCglnXn0Sut4N0w2qp7iixZuXMmf3liI~RQ~WJYwrlNCDHMXjlu9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The ratio between stellar mass and galaxy radius as a function of rotational velocity, where radius is defined as 2.2 disc scalelengths and the velocity is corrected for inclination. Comparison data are from the same sources as in Fig.\u00a06. The dashed line indicates v2\u00a0=\u00a0GM*/r. The lensed galaxies and some data from the other samples, in particular from SHiZELS, lie along this line, indicating that their dynamics are dominated by baryons in the discs. There is no apparent systematic difference between disc-like (filled symbols) and mergers/dispersion-dominated systems (open symbols) in the lensed samples. Offsets from this line are likely related to the gas fractions of the galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig7.tiff\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/17053676/stv686fig7.tiff\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig7.tiff\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"17053676\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/450/2/10.1093/mnras/stv686/2/stv686fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265322&Signature=e2WC9jDCmp4RGxJcElnnMAdkJT5Nonxr06ljHeb6cx1nyln~ygabJ5ddFVU8BwIlZdUfCcu7km7SkIeHDI8Px4IRTd03IkJO1e3hJQTUR6OFAsAC~-sMWxjkP3r8JcM7YRfHpGTCmIM45syA-JmmHCtCfUNMGfLmaa6-U23ps~39cLqNNEHMm-c8C2GvWKbfi7DJT5X3wY0lelJaXcQOg-vZK6xZmkz4zWWcLqOmwQ~VrepiCJ5w~ieWfnKfOMkPAl7~V3NGFforWSXKv2BQrO0zJdRaRLmfpJq7YJLZlmyDGSlcVoiAYSfgrxngIpDGiQ47NiPv8IgIvr2sa5oKjw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=17053676&ar=982124&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv686fig7.tiff\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ratio between stellar mass and galaxy radius as a function of rotational velocity, where radius is defined as 2.2 disc scalelengths and the velocity is corrected for inclination. Comparison data are from the same sources as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The dashed line indicates <em>v</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>GM</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>r</em>. The lensed galaxies and some data from the other samples, in particular from SHiZELS, lie along this line, indicating that their dynamics are dominated by baryons in the discs. There is no apparent systematic difference between disc-like (filled symbols) and mergers/dispersion-dominated systems (open symbols) in the lensed samples. Offsets from this line are likely related to the gas fractions of the galaxies.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=17053677 id=\"17053677\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Star-forming clumps</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">With the high spatial resolution afforded by gravitational lensing, it is possible to extract star-forming clumps from lensed galaxies on scales comparable to giant H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in local galaxies. It has long been noted that galaxies in the high-redshift Universe tend to be \u2018clumpier\u2019 than their local counterparts, with clumps often dominating the host galaxies\u2019 morphologies and giving rise to \u2018clump cluster\u2019 and \u2018chain\u2019 galaxies (e.g. Cowie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Elmegreen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Elmegreen &amp; Elmegreen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Numerous high-redshift galaxy surveys have isolated clumps and analysed their properties on \u223c\u00a0kpc scales (F\u00f6rster Schreiber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Wisnioski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>), but to compare them directly to star formation in the local Universe, which takes place in H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions on scales of \u223c100\u00a0pc, the spatial resolution afforded by gravitational lensing is required (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>; Livermore et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Different studies of star-forming clumps have used a variety of methods to detect and isolate them from their host galaxies. Discussions of the merits of various techniques can be found in Wisnioski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). We adopt the same method as in Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) and use the 2D version of <span class=\"small-caps\">clumpfind</span> (Williams, de Geus &amp; Blitz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>). This routine uses multiple isophotes, starting by defining clumps in the brightest regions and then moving down through the isophote levels. Any isolated contours are defined as new clumps, and any which enclose an existing peak are allocated to that clump. A contour which encloses two or more existing peaks has its pixels divided between them using a \u2018friends-of-friends\u2019 algorithm. We define the lowest contour at 3\u03c3, where \u03c3 is the standard deviation of pixels in the underlying galaxy. We then add additional contours in 1\u03c3 intervals up to the peak in the image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For IFU data, Genzel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) advocate defining clumps in slices in velocity. We test this method with our data and find that it produces similar results to using the integrated intensity maps, and where it does produce clumps that are not evident in the integrated maps, they are marginal detections found only in the lowest (3\u20134\u03c3) contour levels. We therefore use the integrated H\u03b1 (or H\u03b2) maps to define clumps. This has the added advantage of being the method most easily comparable to the narrow-band imaging in Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>), where we used maps of H\u03b1 integrated over a wide velocity range.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To ensure self-consistency across the entire sample of lensed arcs, we reanalyse the intensity maps of the Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) sample to extract clumps with <span class=\"small-caps\">clumpfind</span>. Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>) used a single isophote per galaxy to extract their clump properties, whereas the algorithm developed by Livermore et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) used the noise properties of the image to robustly define a series of isophote levels in a way that does not require any fine tuning. The variation in methods means that the clumps extracted are not identical; a lower isophote will increase both the size and luminosity of the extracted clump, and vice versa. Generally, we use lower isophote levels than Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), leading to larger sizes (but within \u223c1\u03c3 of the published values) with correspondingly higher luminosities. The primary difference is that we also extract some smaller, lower luminosity clumps that are missed when adopting a single isophote.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Once the clumps are defined, we sum the spectra in their component pixels and fit a Gaussian emission line (a single line for H\u03b1 or a triplet for H\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]) to obtain their intensity and velocity dispersion. For those galaxies observed in H\u03b2, we estimate the equivalent H\u03b1 intensity by assuming case B recombination and a Calzetti et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) extinction curve based on the attenuation <em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub> estimated from the SED fitting. No additional extinction is assumed in the nebular lines. Thus, the estimated H\u03b1 luminosity, <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub> is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nL_{\\rm {H}\\alpha } = 2.86 \\times 10^{\\frac{A_V}{7.96}} L_{\\rm {H}\\beta }.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">From <em>L</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub>, we calculate the SFR using the prescription of Kennicutt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998a</a>) adapted to a Chabrier (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) IMF and extinction <em>A</em><sub>H\u03b1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.82\u2009<em>A</em><sub><em>V</em></sub>.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The effective radius, <em>r</em>, of the clump is estimated by summing the area of all pixels contained in the clump, <em>A</em>. We then subtract the area of the effective source-plane PSF in quadrature and define an effective radius <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nr = \\sqrt{\\frac{A}{\\pi }}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify 50 clumps in our sample, with between 1 and 9 clumps per galaxy, and list the derived properties in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"17053686\" scrollto-destination=\"17053686\"></a>\r\n<div Eye-1\u00a0</td><td>600\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0100\u00a0</td><td>25.\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06.\u00a0</td><td>41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a015\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cosmic Eye-2\u00a0</td><td>500\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0100\u00a0</td><td>12.\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a014\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Radius<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> All quantities are corrected for lensing where appropriate. (a): the clump radius is calculated as described in the text, using the area enclosed by an isophote and assuming circular symmetry. The error bar encompasses an alternative definition using the FWHM of the clump emission line profile. (b): SFR is calculated from the total H\u03b1 or H\u03b2 flux enclosed in the isophote and is corrected for extinction. (c): the velocity dispersion, \u03c3, is the mean local value within the clump and is deconvolved for the local velocity gradient.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;
